Kidman Bares Soul (and Body Parts) In a Bold, Ironic, Thoughtful Film

Halina Reijn is a well-regarded Dutch actress. Since her debut as a
writer/director with the film "Instinct" (2019), she's shown some deft
skill on the other side of the camera. "Instinct" centers on an affair
between an experienced psychologist and a serial rapist being considered
for release from prison. The film explores feminism, sex and power.
"Babygirl" revisits these same topics.

Romy (Nicole Kidman) is the CEO of a robotics company in NYC. She's
tightly controlled, perhaps even a little obsessive. (She puts
handwritten notes in her kids' knapsacks.) Romy goes to therapy, gets
regular botox injections and engages in a wide variety of other
activities in a futile effort to control her appearance, her feelings
and everything else around her. Into her life saunters Samuel (Harris
Dickinson - "Triangle of Sadness"), an intern at the company. Romy
becomes his mentor. Right. During their initial ten-minute meet and
greet, Samuel blurts out "I think you like to be told what to do." He's
mortified. She's flustered and thrilled. Soon enough, they begin an
affair. He revels in telling his boss what to do. She enjoys being told.
What's fascinating about their interactions is the raw nature of it all.
Both are responding to feelings, intuitions and urges they don't fully
understand. Samuel's "commanding" presence is actually riddled with
self-doubt. At one point, he says, "I scare myself sometimes." Romy,
too, is chock-full of contradictions. She's a powerful female CEO in a
male-dominated field who's terrified to ask for what she really wants.

Expect both Kidman and Dickinson to be in several awards conversations.
Kidman is arguably the most courageous A-lister working today. She's
fearless about baring her soul - or her body parts. (Check out TV's "Big
Little Lies" and "The Perfect Couple," the films "Eyes Wide Shut," "Dead
Calm," "To Die For" - you'll get the idea.) Here, the immersion of both
actors in these challenging roles is enough to make this project
must-see viewing.

This film is occasionally uncomfortable, frequently disconcerting and
consistently complex. In interviews, Reijn has expressed her admiration
for "9 ¬Ω Weeks," "Fatal Attraction," "Secretary" and the work of Dutch
director Paul Verhoeven ("Showgirls," "Basic Instinct"). However, her
appreciation doesn't stop her from turning the erotic thriller genre on
its head. In "Babygirl," the power figure is obviously female. The
ambivalence and self-doubt of her two main characters undermines the
stereotype of the always-confident man in charge. At one point, Romy
blurts out that she has not had an orgasm in 25 years of marriage. Her
husband, Jacob, is played by heartthrob Antonio Banderas. Jacobs works
in theater. Currently, he's directing "Hedda Gabler," Henrik Ibsen's
play about a woman constrained by society and trapped in a loveless
marriage. Clearly, Reijn has taken great delight in crafting a world
filled with so many ironies and contradictions.

"Babygirl" develops several provocative ideas. The film implies that sex
is the area of life where we are all most prone to embarrassment and
self-doubt - and least likely to say what we want. It also suggests that
sex is the human activity most consistently associated with confusion
and shame. In addition, Writer/Director Reijn takes a few jabs at
conventional female empowerment. At one point, a subordinate looks at
Romy accusingly and says, "I genuinely believed women with power would
behave differently."

"Babygirl" is a film that asks a lot of questions without offering many
answers. If you need a film that makes decisive statements about the
human condition, this isn't for you. It's a film that's unapologetically
raw and messy (read "European"). But if you're open to playful
ambiguity, provocation and a bracing dose of confusion, this film is
well worth your time.

CEO cheats on her husband the movie

The story follows a narcissistic female CEO who becomes infatuated with
the office's most oppressive, hypersexualized intern, leading her to
cheat on her husband, all told through a romanticized, emotional lens.

The intern's predatory behavior is disturbingly rewarded, and hypocrisy
runs rampant in this movie. Perhaps in a half-hearted attempt to explore
the contradictions of the female psyche. Even if so, the film remains
unrealistic, slow, strange, and dull.

You don't have to find it sexy...

I had heard this film was terrible so I went in expecting very little
but thought it was actually very good. So many of the negative reviews
here seem to centre on whether the viewer found it erotic or not, which
so misses the point. It's a human story of flawed humans, their desires
(not yours) and the risks they take as well as the sacrifices they make
(this woman was having unfulfilling sex for decades and we know that's
not news). The Harris Dickinson character is immature and nervous (and
perfectly dressed in sweats, rucksack and ill-fitting suits), trying to
find his way - those who thought he was arrogant and unbelievable must
have had a layer missing. Nicole's character is a stereotype, sure, but
so what? I found her portrayal of a sexually frustrated wife and mother
to be realistic, the complexities of power in the workplace, especially
with her assistant, also pretty true to life.

All the way through, I empathised with her and the state one gets in
when consumed by desire... the guy is so young, he IS cocky but that's
literally the ignorance of youth - that veil comes down in private
moments. To make a movie about a high powered woman who risks it all for
an affair with a young man is fraught with risks and cliches but I
really thought the director avoided all that. It's good!

A Classic Affair Story Made Compelling By Its Cast

7.5/10 Affair stories were never my cup of tea, and for those who feel
the same, Babygirl is the best that you could possibly taste, Nicole
Kidman and Harris Dickinson elevate the film with their strong
performances, portraying characters who are as morally wrong as they are
manipulative, Dickinson, in particular, delivers a performance that
feels raw and unsettling, making his character control and mind games
felt real, Antonio Banderas is also a standout as this good father
figure as well as their daughter played by Esther Rose McGregor and
Vaughan Reilly, ultimately, Babygirl remains a typical affair story that
there's wasn't too much new thing in it, a little bit too long, but
still what makes it good is the strength of its performances and
characters, it's a well-produced film, though story-wise, it treads
familiar ground.

Just outstanding.

The score and soundtrack were both terrific. The scene where Harris
Dickinson dances to Jesus to a Child by George Michael was spectacular.

Overall, this was a good film and an enjoyable watch.

Definitely better than Fifty Shades of Grey

I intentionally avoid all trailers and go into movies knowing as little
as possible. This is an example of when that mostly beneficial strategy
backfires. I would never have chosen a movie made for bored and
unfulfilled wives, where the main draw is the "thrill of the wrong."

With some decent filmmaking aspects, good performances, and a meager
attempt at being artistic, it's not as atrocious as Fifty Shades of
Grey. But the end result is the same, a trashy waste of time. It's
extremely boring and useless, never amounting to anything or going in
any interesting directions.

Certain aspects of this movie remind me of another 2024 release, The
Substance. It also stars an aging actress with themes of trying to stay
young, explicit scenes, and attempts at being artistic. But the
difference couldn't be more drastic. The Substance succeeds at
entertaining you, shocking you, and creating a memorable piece of art.
Whereas Babygirl is just low class smut.

Good movie, over aggressive hate comments

The movie was good at conveying their point about the consequences of
repressed desires and how shame and social expectations can cause it
especially in older women who have been socialized to be that way. I
loved it and the message that it was conveying. I have gone to watch
this movie more times than I would like to admit and have loved even
more each time. The plot is CLEAR and OBVIOUS you just have to pay
attention to get it and if you don't have the attention span for a two
hour movie don't watch. The writer-director Halina Reijn said that this
movie was like a response to Eyes Wide Shut and she was right. The main
difference is that IN MY OPINION Babygirl is 1000% better. Were there
parts that I wished could have been fleshed out more? Yes, but it is an
A24 movie so they had to work within the budget. While the movie is
about sex and desire it wasn't as nearly pornographic as Eyes Wide Shut
(which Halina said was on purpose). Also it's not really a D/s movie
like 50 Shades of Grey or Secretary and IT WASN'T SUPPOSED TO BE so
tailor your expectations. This movie STARTS the conversation about the
orgasm gap. It was EXTREMELY CLEAR in the TRAILER AND THE DESCRIPTION
that Nicole's character was going to be having an affair with her intern
so if you have a problem with movie characters cheating don't watch.
Halina has described the film as a cautionary tale on what NOT TO DO so
you don't follow Romy's mistakes but that she is not a writer/director
that wants to punish her leads. So many people are review bombing this
movie for no actual genuine reason if you read the comments. You can
tell they were barely watching or making superficial comments about
Nicole's face (which is literally apart of the freaking plot). The movie
is awkward on purpose. It's intentionally meant to have cringey moments
because neither character knows what they're doing since they have never
explored/acted on the desires portrayed in the film. It's a good film
for what it is, trying to over compare and over associate it to films
that have a similar premise does it a disservice and takes away from the
messaging as a whole. After all the GLARING taglines and warnings about
what the movie was about when it was being promoted and if the concept
doesn't interest you and I cannot stress this enough don't watch it and
don't hate watch it. It's not meant for you and that's okay.

Wish it was more like a real thriller

Babygirl is written and directed by Halina Reijn. This is Halina Reijn's
third directorial venture, Babygirl, sees her once again step behind the
camera, bringing an ambitious psychological drama to life. Starring
Nicole Kidman as Romy, alongside Harris Dickinson as Samuel and Antonio
Banderas, the film delves into themes of self-image, power, and
psychological manipulation. While the setup hints at a strong
female-driven narrative, Babygirl struggles to find its footing, falling
short of its potential as a gripping thriller.

The opening act establishes Romy as an enigmatic, highly accomplished
woman grappling with her own inner demons. Nicole Kidman delivers a
nuanced performance, perfectly embodying Romy's external perfection and
internal conflict. However, this initial exploration feels overly drawn
out, leaning heavily on exposition rather than action. While it provides
a foundation for Romy's character, the pacing falters, making it
difficult to stay engaged.

The middle section aims to build the relationship between Romy and
Samuel, her younger and seemingly manipulative partner. Harris Dickinson
portrays Samuel with an unsettling charm, and the pair's mind games add
intrigue but fail to sustain momentum. The film repeatedly falls back on
surface-level provocations, particularly sexual tension, which feels
excessive rather than illuminating.

Finally, the last act delivers the tension promised by the film's
premise, albeit not entirely in the way one might hope. The stakes rise
on a personal level for Romy, and Reijn successfully heightens the
emotional intensity. However, the lack of focus on her professional
life-hinted as a critical aspect of her identity-undermines the broader
tension. The corporate drama, which could have provided another
dimension of stakes and conflict, is conspicuously absent.

In conclusion, Babygirl is a film that may appeal to those seeking a
slow-burn psychological character study. However, viewers expecting an
intense, tightly-knit thriller with far-reaching consequences may walk
away disappointed.

Quite flashy, painfully stupid, truly empty and incredibly tedious

This is simply another bright candy wrapper from A24, like far too much
of their output. Consequently, you have the crisp, high-definition
shots, some interesting scene transitions, consistently annoying and
repetitive soundtrack choices with sound mixing insistent on making that
music far too loud (curse Nolan for making it "cool" with Interstellar)
and a gnawing void at its core.

I think this was MEANT to be a narrative of Kidman's uptight,
controlling CEO having her desire for submissiveness unlocked by
Dickinson's intern and ultimately reigniting passion for life. The
problem here is that she NEVER actually seems in control of ANYTHING. In
a performance reminiscent of a similarly trash character from Jurassic
World, Kidman's character is basically always apologetic, always giving
in to people who are supposedly her inferiors at work after only token
protest and unable to exercise any power in her family either. We are
meant to believe an underling could just write a CEO into a mentorship
program without her knowledge and she would simply shrug and accept,
rather than cancelling the thing and kicking the underling out
immediately? Her company is meant to be in the business of coldly
eliminating countless warehouse jobs through automation; yet she never,
ever evidences the cold grip one would have to have to go through with
that.

Likewise, Dickinson's character just comes across as a dead-eyed creep
to me. It's hilarious that he is simultaneously a former dog trainer, an
intern at this high-powered company doing....something (he is literally
NEVER shown with any kind of a responsibility) and also a bartender in
time outside of the internship (one would think being a certified dog
trainer would pay far more than bartending and obviate the need for it,
but what do I know?) That he is also able to juggle all that and also
not one but multiple relationships without looking dead tired all the
time is even funnier. Nothing about his performance makes it convincing
how he is able to get away with repeatedly undermining his CEO from the
very start - nor what actually makes him so attractive to some three
women across the narrative. The way his character is written comes
across like textbook PUA wish fulfilment; the fact this thing was
directed by a woman might be the strongest evidence ever that some women
do find the whole "negging" mess attractive.

Beyond that, the film does grasp at a few other topics (AI! Kidman's
husband stage theater! Their elder daughter being an unfaithful
lesbian!) but has nothing meaningful to say about any of it. The
dialogue in general is remarkably bad, to the point so many
conversations are just tiresome. I was bored and hoping for it to be
over even before the halfway mark - hardly a good sign for anything, but
especially damning for a supposed erotic thriller. It's funny how the
most obvious explanation for Dickinson's transparently gaslighting act -
that he is simply aiming to sleep his way to the top - is not even
considered by anyone in the company, and the whole thing chooses to end
with a literal whimper.

Pretty Good Movie

Rating - 7.0: Overall, a pretty good movie that is carried by its
aesthetic and Nicole Kidman's performance, but it is held back by its
lackluster writing.

Direction - Pretty Good: The direction on a macroscale is pretty good as
they created an aesthetic that really suited the movie; The direction on
a microscale is pretty good as they used tension and cringe to really
heighten the scandal and power dynamic between the two; The storytelling
is pretty simple; They use tension very well as the movie uses this to
make the moments between the two leads uncomfortable; The movie is very
much told from the female perspective and the director does a good job
showing this

Story - Decent: The concept is interesting, but the story itself is
pretty bland and predictable; The plot structure is very simple;
Character writing is good, as you get a sense of how Romy's personal
struggles and power dynamic are influencing her decisions, and Samuel's
mystery helps make this an intriguing relationship for Romy

Screenplay - Decent to Pretty Good: The dialogue is sound but feels a
little too Gen Z; the humor is decent; the symbolism is profound as the
movie tackles issues with power dynamics, women in power, and sexual
fantasies; the foreshadowing is not good as events toward the end just
happen because that is what you expect

Acting - Pretty Good: Nicole Kidman - Good to Very Good (A very
vulnerable performance as she shows why she is one of the best in
Hollywood; She shows a wide range of emotions; She has pretty good
chemistry with Dickinson), Harris Dickinson - Pretty Good to Good (He
does the best with what is written for the character as his charisma
suits the role; He has pretty good chemistry with Nicole Kidman), Sophie
Wilde - Decent to Pretty Good (Plays the assistant character well and
has decent chemistry with Kidman), Antonio Banderas - Pretty Good (An
experienced actor who gets his moments to show his work but is not
really given that much screen time), Rest of the cast - Decent to Pretty
Good (More about the main cast, but the remaining cast does well in
supporting roles)

Score - Pretty Good: Helps establish the tone and aesthetic of the
movie;

Cinematography - Good: Really enjoyed the cinematography as it gave it
an aesthetic that really fit the hustling nature of the New York
business world; Really enjoyed how they used the glass reflection as
somewhat of a mirror

Editing - Good: The movie felt well-edited, especially toward the end

Pacing - Pacing is a little all over the place because it seems slow in
many moments, yet they just speed through plot points in other moments;
The passage of time is not really clear, so you have no idea what the
time period is

Climax - Climax is all right but not really the best in execution;

Tone - Tone is very much an erotic thriller;

Final Notes - I liked the aesthetic of the movie more than the actual
story;

How could she do that?

Nicole Kidman delivers a virtuoso performance in Babygirl, anchoring the
film with her usual intensity. Her portrayal is both commanding and
tender, elevating every scene she's in. Antonio Banderas and Harris
Dickinson also shine in well-crafted roles that give them plenty of
material to flex their considerable talents.

The opening sequence sets the tone, drawing the audience in with a blend
of sex and errotica. As the story unfolds, the film builds on this
foundation, delivering moments of beauty, intrigue, and drama. However,
despite its promising trajectory, Babygirl stumbles at the finish line.
The ending feels like a narrative cop-out that undermines the emotional
investment built throughout the film.

While the conclusion may leave some viewers unsatisfied, the journey to
get there is still worth taking. Kidman's performance alone is reason
enough to watch, and the strong supporting cast ensures there's plenty
to admire along the way.

Hard to believe

Suspension of disbelief-I'm always willing to open my mind to the world
of any given story. But the plot needs to meet me halfway.

It may sound exaggerated, but this is my honest impression: this movie
doesn't have a single scene that's remotely believable. Not a single
one. From the very first minute (literally the first minute of the film)
to the final scene, passing through every moment in between. And it's
important to point out that it's not about doubting the existence of
people with very unusual fantasies; rather, the situations in this movie
are completely implausible. I'm not talking about one or two moments,
but every scene, the entire film. There are even moments where the movie
openly flirts with the ridiculous (there were two or three instances
where I heard people in the theater laughing- at the sheer nonsense of
the situations and lines).

Nicole Kidman is an amazing actress, no doubt about that. The problem
isn't with her performance. But I can imagine that she gets more than a
dozen offers to work on different projects, and she has the luxury of
choosing which ones to take on. And for me, it's really hard to believe
this was the best project she had on the table.

Great acting, character development could use some work

Nicole Kidman shines in unpretentious sexual thriller

Dutch director Halina Reijn writes and directs a sexual thriller that
manages to have moments of remarkable seduction, but which drags on a
bit, preventing it from wrapping up more fully.

Nicole Kidman in her fantasies.

At 57, Nicole Kidman continues to captivate as the great feme fatale she
has always been, and this time she does it with the maturity of an
actress who allows herself to do what she wants and do it well and shine
as in her best times. In a leading role where her role as Romy is
everything to make this thriller work. Kidman carries on her shoulders
the masterful moments that the director achieves and also makes the less
graceful points that the film has much more sustainable. Having Kidman
being seduced, exploiting her sexuality and satisfying her desires is an
entertaining erotic journey that best sums up the film created by Halina
Reijn , who with the character that the director contains in her
staging, truly manages to give us sequences that raise the temperature
and sit on the throne of those great classics of this type of genre in
cinema, making it clear that it comes close, but does not equal it.

A stimulating journey, despite its weaknesses.

The film is not entirely well-rounded, mainly because it goes on longer
than it should or gets tangled up in a couple of subplots that take away
more than they add. However, the skill of a fairly solid cast that
accompanies Kidman, such as Harris Dickinson or Antonio Banderas, allows
this erotic journey to work despite its flaws that can be uncomfortable,
along with a successful direction by its director who knows what she
wants to show and how to show it even if it goes on longer than
necessary.

A soundtrack that manages to give that extra something.

Perhaps one of the most significant successes of the film is its
brilliant soundtrack by Cristobal Tapia de Veer, which elevates the best
sequences of the film to the rhythm of INXS or captivating electronic
music that play a great complement to the proposal they are offering us.

Conclusion.

An erotic thriller that shines thanks to its protagonist and a director
who knows what she's doing. In any case, it's a film that doesn't end up
being completely rounded and promises more than it ends up delivering at
the end of its credits, but it's entertaining, has brilliant moments of
eroticism and dares to give something more in the search for personal
satisfaction of its protagonist. It's a fun game that's worth getting
into and enjoying, especially for the queen Nicole Kidman.

Babygirl

Business executive "Romy" (Nicole Kidman) is initially impressed with
the dog-handling skills of "Samuel" (Harris Dickinson) but when she
discovers that he is to be an intern in her e-packaging company
something else starts to draw her to the man. We already know that
though happily enough married to "Jacob" (Antonio Banderas) she's not
exactly fulfilled in the bedroom department, and "Samuel" seems to sense
that it's an area that maybe he can help with. Were not just talking
sex, here - oh. No. This is about a lady with fantasy of being
dominated. About her surrendering control completely, and if you're
going to do that at all, then why not this tall, handsome and
mischievous bit of rough? Of course, like any addiction - it starts to
get out of control as the relationship dynamic changes quite profoundly
and others start to put two and two together. At times this is quite
funny, and milk seems to play a central role from time to time, but as a
cinematic version of something akin to tantric, it doesn't really work.
Neither of these actors are afraid to get naked yet neither do,
simultaneously, here. Indeed I'm sure I saw his black Calvin's shining
from under the sheet when the intimacy consultant was at their busiest.
I didn't need nudity to augment their unique sort of passion, but I did
expect something way more natural, visceral even, and I didn't get it.
It's filmed in such a disjointed and bitty fashion, there's no attempt
to characterise or contextualise either of these people and in the end I
felt like this was little better than a titillation for it's stars that
didn't really aspire to engage those watching any more than age-related
porn might. Dickinson isn't remotely charismatic and the premiss falls
flat quickly, especially when the quite aggravating intervention of
"Esme" (Sophie Wilde) rather summed the shallowness of the whole thing
up. "Eyes Wide Shut" (1999) or "Beach Rats" (2017) showcase both their
talents amidst a sexually charged environment far better: this is all
forgettable, over-hyped, stuff.

Raw and naturalistic erotic drama

A high-powered, no-nonsense corporate CEO (Nicole Kidman) has everything
going for her and likes to be in charge of things - except for in the
bedroom. She's never been sexually satisfied by her husband of 19 years
(Antonio Banderas), when she meets a young, fumbling intern (Harris
Dickinson), who might just share her particular desires. Dubbed as the
comeback of the erotic thriller, a subgenre that had its heyday in the
early 1990s, Babygirl actually has much more in common with its most
obvious inspiration, Secretary from 2002. Though, contrary to E. Edward
Gray's situation in that film - a boss at the office who also enjoyed
being the boss in his sexual encounters - Romy Mathis has much more
trouble reconciling her sexual preferences with her professional
persona. This conflict is arguably one of this film's strongest points.
Writer/director Halina Reijn's raw, naturalistic approach gives the film
realism, but it's a frustrating form of realism: We're let in on the
characters' inner secrets and urges, but we're constantly kept in the
dark about the machinations that govern them. Romy and Samuel are
novices in their own world, giving Kidman and Dickinson numerous scenes
to explore and display their chops, which they do with proud boldness,
but few in which the film offers us any release. We're invited to
observe, not to take part and feel. And the strangely moralistic
Banderas character, who is supposed to represent the viewer in some way,
doesn't seem to belong, neither in the film nor in Romy's world.

Don't Bang the Intern & Other Cinematic Lessons

Nicole Kidman is the only real gravity in Baby Girl, a film that flirts
with psychological complexity but keeps defaulting to clich√© kink;

Her performance, elegant, almost clinical, deserves a script that trusts
the audience's intellect. Instead, the movie builds an implausible
romance whose origins strain credibility from the first act: a chance
encounter stretched into obsession without the emotional scaffolding
that would make it believable. The relationship at the film's core feels
like a screenwriting exercise rather than human behaviour. The initial
attraction is presented as a given, a cinematic axiom rather than
something earned. We never see the genuine psychological drift that
would explain why Kidman's character, a woman of discipline and interior
life, would surrender to such a transparently manipulative dynamic. What
could have been a study in projection and loneliness becomes instead an
aestheticized shortcut.

Mainstream filmmaking has turned forbidden mentorship into a default
sexual tension template. Baby Girl clings to that pattern: age versus
youth, intellect versus impulse, control versus chaos. But there is no
interrogation of why these power dynamics persist, just another glossy
reproduction of the same tropes. The film flirts with subversion but
never commits to it, allowing Kidman's gravitas to do all the moral
heavy lifting while the camera fetishizes imbalance.

Midway through, a George Michael track blares over a surreal release
sequence that feels almost parodic. It is meant to be ironic catharsis,
a moment of pop-infused abandon, but plays as juvenile escapism. Rather
than deepen the emotional consequences, the scene trivializes them,
signalling pleasure as shorthand for liberation without interrogating
the repression that preceded it.

The movie's greatest failure is its refusal to explore the psychology
behind pleasure and transgression. Every erotic beat is surface level,
style replacing insight. Trauma, repression, and the need for validation
hover at the margins but are never metabolized. What could have been a
modern Dangerous Liaisons for the therapy generation instead becomes a
fashionably lit fantasy that tiptoes around the very depths it hints at.

Nicole Kidman turns in a performance of eerie control, a woman
half-aware that she is trapped in a screenplay that does not trust her
intelligence. Baby Girl mistakes mood for meaning and risk for
revelation. In the end, it is a beautifully dressed case study in
Hollywood's inability to move on.

Sex and Sensibility

I would love to heap praise on this movie, but much of what makes it
exceptional is tied to moments and details I wouldn't want to spoil.
That said, I can say this: it's a rare example of an erotic film where
the sex scenes are deeply character-driven, not gratuitous indulgences
designed for the director's satisfaction.

This film is mature, intelligent, and daring, operating on a level that
respects the audience's ability to think and feel deeply. Unlike the
melodramatic thrillers we often associate with eroticism, such as Fatal
Attraction, this movie offers a refreshingly realistic exploration of
sexuality-one that acknowledges its profound complexity.

Desire is rarely straightforward. Our passions and kinks often defy easy
explanation, arising from parts of ourselves we may not fully
understand. Yet, we feel them with undeniable force. For once, here is a
film that gets it-one that portrays the messiness of human intimacy
without reducing it to a spectacle or a simplistic morality tale.

This is a story that understands its subject on a visceral level,
offering a nuanced, unflinching portrayal of the way sexuality weaves
through our lives. It's a film that challenges, excites, and provokes
thoughtful reflection-something that is all too rare in this genre.

"Babygirl" Tries to Be Bold but Ends Up Bland

"Babygirl" had all the ingredients for something bold and compelling,
but it ended up feeling pretty tame and oddly far-fetched. I really
liked the overall message - it's an important subject that should be
explored more - but the movie itself just felt messy. It never really
committed to being one thing, bouncing between an erotic thriller, a
workplace drama, and a cautionary tale without fully landing any of
them.

Nicole Kidman is, of course, stunning, but she felt miscast here. With
all the surgeries, her expressions are so limited that it made it hard
to connect with her character on a deeper level. (And don't get me wrong
- I'm all for people doing what makes them happy, but in a role like
this, range is crucial)

Overall, Babygirl had potential, but it never quite found its footing.
It raises an important conversation, but as a film, it doesn't stick the
landing.

Here we go again

Female "empowerment" taking on the form of a storyline involving a much
older woman going after a much younger man.

This time though the dude looks old enough to be her grandson.

How much further are they going to push this tired old scheme?

I know old Hollywood was filled with older actors being cast opposite
younger actresses, but the plot of the story didn't have to do with her
age. And the older actor's character targeting her because she was
younger. Outside of Lolita, of course.

It seems like movies nowadays are lazy, with this same old older
woman/younger man storyline, but the older woman going after the man is
purposeful, and his age is used as some sort of titillating, validating
factor.

Funny though when male characters are portrayed with much younger
actresses, they are perceived as dirty old men going through a midlife
crisis.

When an older woman does it she is seen as "chic" and "liberated." As
someone else pointed out on here, what's with the hypocrisy and double
standard.

This storyline is becoming real tiresome, but if they want to keep
pushing it, then call it what it is. A dirty old woman looking to
validate herself by nabbing a younger man. To prove to herself she is
still worthy. I mean, that's what women have said about men in the same
situation.

Haven't we also heard for years that actresses who age are aging out of
so many movies ("unfairly") by comparison to older actors who can still
get great roles.

Hardly. In fact, there are a lot of great roles for older actresses.

But why do so many have to do with this theme of hooking up with a much
younger man.

Surely there are better parts for women out there that have some
substance rather than dummying down to this same old trope.

Let's see some creativity in storytelling. Let's see some storylines
where some of our great, older actresses are cast, but there isn't yet
another young man involved.

We need to see women empowered through their skills and offerings as
successful women. Not just their attempts at validating themselves with
younger men.

Despite the heat, it doesn't make you sweat

Babygirl is a production that I have followed since the beginning and
that caught my attention immediately, the role reversal, seductive and
fetishistic tone of the story with a courageous confrontation of norms
filled with conflicts and manipulation from all sides that heated up
this story of passion. Unfortunately, Babygirl is a categorical example
of the difference between intention and execution.

Kidman's joy in her beautiful promise and projects with female directors
is palpable. In a position of power and influence, Kidman deeply
understands the freedom she has and explores this power behind the
screen to help bring Halina Reijn's vision to life and this is
admirable, her dedication on screen contaminates Harris Dickinson who
also delivers what the story demands. It's a shame that the story can't
keep up with the same brilliance of its protagonists.

There are moments of genius here that manage to bring to life what could
be the polished version of this story, but despite a hot story with two
actors on the boil, Babygirl doesn't manage to melt the ice completely.

I hope Kidman continues with such projects and Reijn continues to polish
her identity, already with great work under her belt with BODIES BODIES
BODIES.

But the result is confusing.

BABYGIRL is bold whereas in a strange way, it remains conservative. It

chemistry with Dickinson, not for a moment their lust for each other was

Furthermore, this movie wanted to be unpredictable and up to some point,

because her character was a hypocrite and manipulative person. I kinda

A banal melodrama with ill concieved psychosexual elements

push-pull

Greetings again from the darkness. Oscar winner Nicole Kidman long ago
entrenched herself as one of the best and most daring actors working
today. Not one to shy away from risky material, she's appeared in such
films as EYES WIDE SHUT (1999), DOGVILLE (2003), BIRTH (2004), and THE
NORTHMAN (2022) to name just a few. It's her talent and willingness to
put herself out there that has earned such respect among peers and fans.
However, despite that admiration, this latest is one of my least
favorite films of the year, and one that I found almost no positives to
discuss. I will readily admit this opinion puts me in the extreme
minority.

The first feature film from writer-director (and actor) Helena Reijn was
BODIES BODIES BODIES (2022), a festival and indie favorite. That success
led to this cast which finds Harris Dickinson (THE IRON CLAW, 2023, and
WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING, 2022) and long-time favorite Antonio Banderas
joining Kidman. Now, despite my negative reaction to this viewing
experience, I do recognize that some credit is due for tackling an
uncomfortable topic - an unethical dominant/submission relationship
between a powerful CEO and her intern. We are supposed to believe Romy
(Kidman) is incredibly important and busy because her cell phone is
constantly in use (but then that's the case for most teenagers, too).
Once again, Hollywood proves that it's clueless on how to authentically
present a business environment.

Further stretching the scenario beyond any realm of believability, cocky
intern Sam assertively pursues a taboo relationship with the big boss
rather than work towards a job offer that most interns focus on. While
there is a bit of fun in the early "will they or won't they"
cat-and-mouse scenes, once things move forward, the film takes on the
tone of a power play parody. "Good girl" draws laughter from the
audience ... as does her suggestion of "Jacob" (her husband's name) as a
safe word.

The ramifications for CEO (or wife and mother) Romy never carry the pain
we would expect, and the threats always seem a bit hollow. None of this
is meant to purport that dominant/submissive desires and relationships
don't exist, only that this extreme is difficult to buy into. On the
bright side, Banderas shines in the moment he flashes his anger, and
it's a real treat to hear "Never Tear Us Apart" by INXS blasting on a
theater sound system. Nicole Kidman is gaining momentum for yet another
Oscar nomination for her performance, so again, I'll admit to being in
the minority with my opinion on this one. Still, I can't bring myself to
recommend, even if I hope you find it more entertaining than I did.

Opens in theaters on December 25, 2024.

The Library as Mirror and Portal: From Romy in "Babygirl" to Angela
Carter's Subversive Wisdom

One often stumbles upon unexpected treasures within the familiar
confines of one's own library. It's akin to discovering a hidden alcove
brimming with untold stories, a serendipitous encounter that hints at
unforeseen avenues of learning. Such moments can forge surprising
connections between seemingly disparate forms of artistic expression.

For the present observer, the initial spark for this intellectual foray
emerged from a rather compelling cinematic portrayal. The character of
Romy, brought to life by Nicole Kidman in Halina Reijn's "Babygirl,"
resonated with a particular strength. Her on-screen presence conveyed a
potent sense of freedom and a nuanced empowerment, striking a chord that
felt both deeply personal and subtly profound. This character, in
essence, became a catalyst, prompting a quiet quest for kindred spirits
in narrative form.

This pursuit led, rather intriguingly, to the literary realm of Angela
Carter. It became apparent that Carter's work engaged with similar
undercurrents. Much like Romy's unconventional strength in "Babygirl,"
Carter's writing revisits well-worn tales with a fresh and often
audacious perspective. She subtly dismantles traditional roles and
delves into themes of power and autonomy with an insightful and
occasionally unsettling gaze. Her reimagining of classic narratives, for
instance, often features protagonists who are far from passive,
possessing a complexity and agency that defies expectation.

The discovery of Angela Carter within the library's hushed aisles,
prompted by the lingering resonance of Nicole Kidman's performance as
Romy in "Babygirl" (penned by Halina Reijn), underscores the fascinating
interplay between different artistic mediums. The cinematic portrayal
served as an unexpected gateway to a literary voice that echoed, in its
own distinct way, those initial stirrings of understanding. In this
light, the library transcends its function as a mere repository of
books, becoming a rather enchanting meeting place where personal
journeys intertwine with the enduring power of story.
Dabbles with interesting topics but does not go deep enough

Here's a recipe for banana bread Ripe bananas. The more brown, the
better.

Butter: Or you can use margarine or oil.

Sugar: Swap brown sugar for white (which makes a denser, moister bread)
or another sugar altogether.

Eggs: Recipe calls for two, but it will still work with only one egg.

Milk: Swap almond milk, kefir, buttermilk, or even water for the liquid.

All-purpose flour: Swap up to half the flour for whole wheat or another
favorite whole-grain flour.

Baking soda. Works as the leavener.

Chopped nuts or chocolate chips. Optional, and totally up to you.

Failed by the writing.

I went in expecting a compelling BDSM-focused film, especially with the
incredible Nicole Kidman leading the cast. What I got, however, was a
movie that barely scratches the surface of BDSM, offering no meaningful
exploration of its dynamics. It lacks a clear message, the dialogue
feels clunky, and the story seems utterly confused about what it wants
to convey. Even the protagonist's motivations are murky, let alone those
of the supporting characters. There is absolutely no chemistry between
the leads, making their relationship feel forced and unconvincing.
Meanwhile, Antonio Banderas, playing the husband and the supposed third
part of the triangle, is almost entirely sidelined, his character
receiving little to no development. I can count on one hand the number
of films that portray BDSM authentically, and this one fails to make the
cut. The same power dynamic was handled with infinitely more nuance,
depth, and emotion in Sanctuary. The blame for this missed opportunity
falls squarely on director and writer Halina Reijn, who squandered an
otherwise excellent cast.

of his behaviour. A woman who, at first sight, seems to have a stable
private life, suddenly falls in love with a young teenager who saves her
from a dog and decides to do everything he wants.

In terms of performance, I think Nichole Kidman does a good job with

understand why he was behaving this way, as he changes from arrogant to

In the end, it seems to me a film that wants to draw people's attention
to a subject that attracts a lot of people around the world nowadays and
push to get money from that. As last word, I can say that it seems to be
nothing more than a copy of 50 shades film.

Banderas saves the show

What frustrates me about Baby Girl is how it never fully delivers on its
potential. It claims to be a sensual and erotic film, but it's more
awkward than anything else. Harris Dickinson's character is poorly
defined-he's supposed to come across as a dominant, seductive, masculine
figure, but instead, he's just an uncomfortable guy who doesn't even
seem to enjoy what he's doing. Are uncomfortable scenes a problem? Not
necessarily. The issue is that the director doesn't commit to anything.
It's not uncomfortable enough to be a psychological thriller, nor is it
erotic enough to explain the characters' motivations. The script feels
half-baked, and as a result, it's easy for viewers to stop believing in
the story-and honestly, I get it.

I gave it the benefit of the doubt mostly because of its technical
aspects. The second half of the film, when it ditches the cheap
eroticism, is where the real tension kicks in. Antonio Banderas steals
the show-his two scenes left me stunned. Other moments, like the
nightclub scene, are very well done. All the awkwardness of the
beginning finds its footing in a suspenseful turn led by Banderas, which
salvages some of what was lost-but not enough. The movie ultimately
feels underwhelming, which is a shame because the script has genuinely
funny moments, and Nicole Kidman delivers a solid performance. Still,
the strong scenes in the second half can't make up for the weak first
half. With a clearer sense of direction, this film could've been so much
better.

Waste of time

Babygirl wants to be daring, but it mostly plays like a hollow fantasy
that mistakes "CEO + affair + taboo vibes" for actual storytelling. The
biggest problem is that there's barely a story here, just a thin setup
meant to feel edgy, without the character work or plot momentum to
justify the time spent.

Harris Dickinson is the film's anchor in the worst way. The performance
is flat and strangely smug, with that dead-eyed, entitled brat energy
that makes his character feel less "dangerous" or "irresistible" and
more like a creepy tween throwing pseudo power games. And the movie
expects you to buy that this is the kind of person who ignites some
sweeping erotic obsession? I didn't feel tension, seduction, or even
curiosity, just discomfort and disbelief.

Nicole Kidman is asked to sell the fantasy as a high-powered robotics
CEO on the edge of an IPO, yet the film's version of leadership is
basically: look polished, float through rooms, and somehow have
unlimited emotional bandwidth for a bizarre affair while apparently
doing no actual work. Are we seriously supposed to believe that this
CEO, at this moment, has the time and headspace to spiral into "weird
affair before the IPO" territory in a way that feels real? The corporate
setting is there for gloss and stakes-on-paper, not because the movie
has anything meaningful to say about power, ambition, risk, or
consequence.

Older women having fantasies and sexual desires isn't shocking news, nor
should it be treated like a revelation. People have every right to want,
to experiment, to blow up a routine, to chase intimacy or adrenaline.
But the film doesn't explore that with insight, humor, or complexity. It
just gestures at it, like it deserves applause for stating the obvious,
then calls it provocative.

In the end, Babygirl isn't erotica, isn't funny, and isn't particularly
interesting. It's not bold so much as empty. Yes, some people have
questionable taste in men. Yes, some people chase extramarital drama to
feel alive. That's not a story. That's a premise. And Babygirl never
becomes more than that.

Desire, Power, and Dangerous Lines

Babygirl surprised me. It's not perfect, but it's bold, messy, and
unlike a lot of erotic thrillers, it tries to dig into the messy parts
of power, desire, and what it means to want something that might destroy
you. Plus Nicole Kidman slays.

‚úÖ What Hit Home 1. Nicole Kidman is magnetic as Romy: She embodies both
control and deep longing. You see someone who is made to be in charge,
yet haunted by what she's not admitting to herself.

2. Samuel (Harris Dickinson) is more than just "young intern": He has an
unsettling calm, as though he senses exactly what boundaries exist and
how far he can nudge them. That push-pull is interesting.

3. Director Halina Reijn's tone: Not just erotic for shock or
titillation, but, many scenes feel like they are holding up a mirror to
things few films dare: sexual need, shame, consent, power imbalance.

4. The cinematography, music, and moments of aesthetic flourish: Some
scenes (the hotel room dances, Romy watching Samuel, the contrast
between her public control and her private self) were visually strong
and emotionally evocative.

‚ùå What Fell Short For Me 1. Underdeveloped backstories: Some of Romy's
trauma (commune, childhood cult, etc.) and Samuel's motivations feel
hinted at more than fully explored. It leaves holes in understanding why
choices get made.

2. Chemistry feels uneven at points: There were moments where the
romance/erotic tension felt rushed or forced, rather than earned.

3. Tone flip-flops: Moves between erotic thrill, psychological drama,
moral critique: ambitious, yes, but sometimes jarring. It occasionally
feels unsure whether it wants to provoke or to reflect.

4. Ending feels both satisfying and unsatisfying: It wraps up some arcs
nicely, but other threads fizzle out. For viewers wanting full closure,
it might frustrate.

‚ú® Favorite Quotes & Moments (No Spoilers)

"To Samuel, sex is a fact. To me, it was an obsession."

The scene where Romy first sees Samuel with the wild dog on the street.

Romy dancing alone, shirtless but not for display.

The lyric/dance moment: "Father Figure" plays, Samuel moves in that
hotel room.

Romy's scenes of reflection.

üåü Final Thoughts

Babygirl is not one-size-fits-all. It's risky, provocative, and will
make some uncomfortable (intentionally). But it also offers something
rare: a woman's perspective on desire, on control, on what you lose when
you give in. It doesn't fully succeed everywhere, but where it does, it
lingers.

If I came away from it reflecting on power, consent, the sacrifices we
hide behind careers and marriages. That means it's done more than just
shock. It did something.

üé• If You Liked This, You Might Also Enjoy: 1. Dangerous Liaisons (1998)
- power, manipulation, desire

2. The Glass House - erotic thrillers with complicated moral stakes

3. Eyes Wide Shut - sexual obsession, repression, and consequence

4. Little Children - marriages, secrets, longings

5. Carol - emotional tension, societal constraints, intimacy.

Babygirl tries to be provocative but lacks the intelligence or
creativity to make an impact.

Babygirl (2024) is yet another attempt at making a "provocative" drama
that leans too much on surface-level shock value rather than compelling
storytelling. The plot, if you can call it that, revolves around an
imbalanced relationship dynamic that lacks any real emotional depth.
There is no real buildup, no effort to make the audience care about
these characters beyond their physical interactions, and certainly no
originality. The film tries to be daring, but instead, it feels like a
predictable series of events with little payoff.

The directing is uninspired, relying on overused shaky cam techniques
that have no business in a drama like this. The cinematography does
nothing to elevate the story, and at times, it feels like the camera is
as lost as the script. The only real standout performance comes from
Antonio Banderas, but he's barely in the movie. Nicole Kidman, despite
her talent, is stuck in a role that feels more about aesthetics than
substance. And of course, we have the usual over-the-top praise for a
"bold sexualized performance," the same kind of overhyped reaction we
saw with Demi Moore in Substance, as if established actors being in
explicit scenes somehow qualifies as groundbreaking cinema.

The script is painfully weak, with dialogue that does little to make the
characters feel real or relatable. The film spends too much time trying
to push a message without taking the time to craft an engaging
narrative. There are moments where it seems like it might go somewhere
interesting, but then it falls back into the same repetitive themes. The
pacing is another issue, dragging through unnecessary moments while
rushing past anything that could have added depth.

The score is outright annoying. It doesn't complement the film or
enhance any of the scenes, it's just there, adding to the discomfort in
all the wrong ways. In the end, Babygirl tries to be provocative but
lacks the intelligence or creativity to make an impact. It's the kind of
movie that confuses shock value with substance, leaving you wondering
what the point of it all was.

The movie was nothing special except for the sex scene.

In her latest film, Babygirl, director Halina Raine wants to explore
human sexual desires and their conflict with love and family, and for
this, she places Nicole Kidman at the center of her film. Have you ever
thought that maybe you could have a decent job, a dynamic family with
children and a loving husband, and at the same time, in a balanced way,
seek to satisfy sexual desires that are abnormal in the eyes of society?
Well, that's what the story of Babygirl is about, but to what extent has
Halina Raine, who in addition to directing and writing the work, managed
to make such a theme a film? Join Vigiato for a review of the film
Babygirl.

Romy Mathis (played by Nicole Kidman) is a successful and powerful woman
who heads the automation of processes by robots at a company in New York
City. She loves her husband and children dearly, but her husband has
never been able to satisfy her sexually as he should. The first scene of
the film begins with the same theme, when Romy, after having sex with
her husband Jacob (played by Antonio Banderas), goes to her laptop and
watches the sex videos she wants. Of course, the problem is not her
husband, Romy is full of abnormal sexual desires that prevent her from
having a normal orgasm. One day, when Romy wants to enter her company, a
dog is attacking her, but a young man stops her and calms the dog. This
man is Samuel, the company's new intern. Samuel (played by Harris
Dickinson) decides to choose him as his mentor after meeting Romy a few
times. From here, Samuel's relationship with Romy is formed, a
relationship in which Romy can satisfy her abnormal sexual desires and
even feel a sense of trust and love from Samuel. But how long can such a
relationship last, and more importantly, how can we ensure that such a
relationship does not harm Roman's family and career?

Oh baby

The film was actually better than I expected. I had seen the trailer and
a couple of interviews, which gave me a mixed impression-Nicole Kidman's
performance was praised, and apparently she even received an award for
it. Personally, I felt she veered heavily into overacting, and I didn't
enjoy it. It was Harris Dickinson's performance that made me want to
watch the film. While the movie is far from perfect, it earns its place
by exploring a woman's deep passions.

Right from the start, the film takes a hit when Nicole Kidman appears on
screen with an oily wig and a forced expression, her face smeared with
messy makeup. In my view, she overacts noticeably. Her shabby appearance
paints a picture of a pitiful woman in the wrong place at the wrong
time. Kidman should have used more subtle expressions-her exaggerated
acting, combined with her botox-stiffened face, gives her a less
appealing presence. She comes across as a depressed, needy woman who
might require medication.

And if she's supposed to be a tough-as-nails CEO, why does she seem so
timid and insecure? She's easily flustered by Harris's words and
reactions. No real CEO would behave like that-they'd know how to keep
their composure in front of an intern. She's completely thrown off when
Harris kisses her, like a little girl. Later, when she finally tries to
assert herself, she comes off as arrogant. In a matter of minutes,
Kidman transforms into a puppy begging for affection, bending to the
will of a nearly unknown young man. That's not believable either. Only
in the final moments of the film do we catch a glimpse of the hardened
CEO when she confronts Sebastiani.

I liked the tie scene, where Nicole smells Harris's tie-I would've done
the same. You can almost smell the cologne. It's a truly sexy moment. I
especially admire Harris's acting; he seems completely at one with his
role. He wears it like a comfortable garment that fits him perfectly.
His captivating gaze draws the viewer in and leaves you wanting more.
Harris Dickinson is the new Brad Pitt.

The film suffers from a lack of plot and solid writing. Kidman also
fails to bring credibility to her role. Just saying she's a CEO doesn't
convince the viewer when she doesn't behave like one. A
leader-especially a female one-is typically poised, stylish, and
confident. It's hard to believe someone in that position would be
rattled by an intern's remarks. Where's the thriller? Nowhere. There are
rushed meetings, but even those feel ordinary-nothing fresh is brought
to the scenes.

The film is shot with brutal realism, exposing every wrinkle, line,
freckle, bony knee, and botox filler-highly unflattering for Nicole
Kidman. She also lacks feminine curves; her nudity isn't arousing, just
puzzling. Of course, she's not expected to look twenty, but it leaves
you wondering why Harris falls for her when there are far more
attractive women nearby. I wish someone else had played the female
lead-someone who could've brought credibility to the role. Kidman comes
off as unconvincing and fake. She fails to portray a confident, seasoned
CEO wrestling with her own desires and ultimately surrendering to them.
Many women have experienced that inner conflict when faced with a
desirable young man, but few actually give in. I wanted to like this
film, and especially Kidman, but unfortunately it left a bland
aftertaste-like drinking a glass of vintage red wine diluted with water.
It's a shame, because this could've been so much better.
No story, no plot twist

A Superficial Attempt at Depth!

Babygirl is an unsuccessful attempt at exploring the complexities of
human desires and psychological relationships. What could have been a
deep and thought-provoking character study ends up as a shallow and
artificial portrayal of sensitive themes.

The characters-especially Romy and Samuel-are so flat and underdeveloped
that the audience struggles to connect with them. Even by the end of the
film, their motivations remain unclear.

The film tries to ride on themes of sexual freedom and self-acceptance,
but it comes across more like a pretentious ad campaign than a
thoughtful piece of cinema. The dialogues are so clich√©d and forced that
they disrupt the viewer's immersion.

The climax and ending are not only unconvincing but feel almost
insulting to viewers who have invested over 90 minutes. The sudden
change in Romy's husband's behavior lacks any emotional or narrative
foundation.

Babygirl tries hard to appear intellectual and thought-provoking, but
beneath its glossy surface, there's little of real substance.

That said, despite its narrative flaws, Babygirl does have a few notable
strengths that set it apart from other psychological dramas. Nicole
Kidman delivers a powerful and layered performance as Romy, portraying
her confusion, strength, and vulnerability with great nuance.

Overall, Babygirl occasionally manages to provoke thought and offers a
visually engaging experience thanks to strong acting and confident
direction, even if it falls short in terms of psychological depth and
narrative coherence.

In the end, Babygirl fails to deliver the emotional and intellectual
depth it promises. Instead, it offers a confusing, preachy, and
ultimately forgettable experience. If you're looking for a film that
truly engages your mind and emotions, this one will likely waste your
time.

the other version of 'fifty shades of grey'

A24 usually has me in its pocket, though this time i'm caught somewhere
between fascination and indifference. Its latest offering proves that a
strong connection doesn't always require extensive romantic
development... although here, it's the physical intensity that takes
center stage.

The script wavers between subtlety and impulse, achieving moments of
genuine tension but sometimes falling into a repetition that wears down
its impact. Still, there are performances that surprise, and others
that, while not at their peak -like nicole kidman, whose high point for
me remains the others- manage to bring to life characters with more
depth than they initially reveal. Although there isn't much character
development, i have to say i liked how they are built; it leaves you
wanting to keep watching them despite the plot.

Visually, it's elegant. There are shots that play with the viewer,
hiding more than they show and letting the imagination fill in the gaps.
There are also flashes of well-handled themes: a strong female presence,
an unexpected character that adds to the whole, and an ending so
decisive it almost redeems everything that came before. A cast that
could be considered inclusive, but doesn't overshadow the film or ruin
it, like in the little mermaid.

It's not a work that makes it onto my personal favorites list, but i
have to admit that, even with its imbalances, it stands a step above
other productions treading similar ground... yes, even those that made a
certain story of a similar tone so famous ('fifty shades of grey')

Another Story of O

Nicole Kidman works so frequently that it's easy to see how some of her
performances might fall under the radar. Released in the US on Christmas
Day, 2024, "Babygirl", distributed by A24, wasn't allowed to fully bloom
in people's minds before awards season; consequently, Kidman wasn't
nominated by BAFTA or by the Academy, though this fearless performance
by the actress is certainly one of her best (she was Golden
Globe-nominated, and she won Best Actress from National Board of
Review). Female CEO in New York City, heading up an automation company,
is brought to her knees (literally) by a coolly arrogant, handsome young
intern. She's been married to a loving man for 19 years, but she's
unfulfilled in the bedroom; once this self-assured kid starts showing
signs that he's got the same kinks that she has (or fantasizes about at
night after her husband goes to sleep), the CEO finds herself meeting
him in hotel rooms and dancing all night at a rave club. But, what burns
hot eventually cools down, and writer-director Halina Reijn is almost
too ready to bring in a veiled threat from our heroine's all-knowing
assistant, tears of worry from her lesbian daughter, and a blistering
retort from her husband, leading to a somewhat limp finish of
"redemption". For the first hour, "Babygirl" is striking and
exciting--like "Nine and 1/2 Weeks" turned up a few notches--but the
finale plays things too safely. Still, Kidman is worth-watching; she's
ready to take this character all the way out on a dangerous limb. ***
from ****

Too smart for the GP

Despite being one of (if not the) most intelligent films of its year,
the vast majority of the general public-and even "film nerds"
(posers)-have proved themselves entirely too stupid to understand its
complex messages and multifaceted quality.

The majority of viewers are so sex-negative that, as soon as they see
sexuality represented on screen, their brains completely shut off.
They're so overwhelmed by their disgust (fueled by internalized sexual
shame and juvenility) that they cannot see beyond it-which is what
creates reviews as incredibly ironic as: "This film was gross." Calling
Babygirl, a film about the negative effects of sexual shame, "gross" is
akin to wearing a dunce hat and telling everyone on the street you eat
chalk.

On the other hand, there are viewers whose brains are too rotted by porn
to understand that it is not simply another 365 Days sex fest. Babygirl
balances meaning and fantasy, which has proven far too complex for many
to handle.

The only real issues with the film are its pacing (it's slow at points),
its visuals (especially color grading), and the fact that if you're not
into the fantasy it sells, there's an element of the film you may not
enjoy to its fullest.

A Stunning Tale of Vulnerability and Strength, Masterfully Directed by
Halina Reijn

I decided to watch Baygirl to support Halina Reijn, a Dutch director I
admire as an actor. What started as a gesture of support quickly turned
into an impressive viewing experience that completely captivated me.

Nicole Kidman's performance was absolutely breathtaking. I had never
seen her like this before: pure, open, vulnerable, and intimate. Her
chemistry with Harris was remarkable; every scene felt like a shifting
balance of power between them, moving from strength to vulnerability and
back again. This dynamic unfolded so naturally, always driven by love as
the central force.

Halina Reijn's directorial choices are nothing short of brilliant. She
captures the vulnerability and strength of a woman in a way that is both
raw and beautiful. Her approach felt genuine and personal, which made it
a deeply emotional and valuable experience for me as a viewer.

Baygirl exceeded my expectations and left me positively surprised. It's
an absolute must-watch-not just for fans of Halina Reijn or Nicole
Kidman, but for anyone who wants to be moved by a powerful film.

Overrated .

I went to watch this movie , believing the hype and incredible marketing
, assuming it was an erotic thriller with a revenge plot line . Boy was
I wrong .

Nicole Kidman plays a sexually dissatisfied CEO, with a clearly
checkered past. Her company hires a bunch of new interns , and one
particular one catches her eye right from the get go , with him asking a
provocative question at a meet and greet . She starts to slowly obsess
over him and begins taking some morally wrong decisions , which
ultimately lead to an absurd affair and the consequences of this affair
is what the entire second half is supposed to be about .

You would think that a movie with an interesting premise like this could
go one of many many thrilling ways . However , it chooses to go nowhere.

A-List superstar Nicole Kidman takes top billing as a fit, high-powered,

Steamy story for middle-aged audience

At its best, Babygirl reflects Nicole Kidman's obsession with staying
young and attractive and her powerlessness against aging. Both her
efforts to stay young and the unavoidable signs of aging are captured on
film, in what almost feels like a cruel documentary. In one instance,
Samuel says she "looks like a Mom" and later on her daughter says she
"looks like grandma". The internal struggle with aging of Romy the
character is a reflection of the struggle of Kidman the actress. It's
the most interesting part of the movie and a truly courageous role for
her.

At its worst, Babygirl is a form of Fifteen Shades of Grey cushioned
with enough correctness to make it acceptable to independent and
middle-aged audiences. Because you see, even in a dominator-dominated
situation, it's all consensual and if you think about it, the dominated
woman really is the one to hold the power. "Okay, guys, we checked the
boxes. You can now roll the steamy BDSM scenes to the rhythm of catchy
hits from the 80's". Let's not even try to hide who the commercial
target of these steamy scenes is.

Unfortunately this second aspect of the film is dominating, and it's
disappointing and silly. Ironically, in this movie about female
empowerment, the character who ends up stealing the show is Samuel.
While everything Romy does has a well laid-out explanation, no effort is
spent on trying to explain Samuel. Because why would you? Men are pigs
and there's no other explanation needed, right? Except that we as the
audience know it's not quite that simple, and we keep wondering what
drives Samuel. Superbly acted by Harris Dickinson, that deviant abuser
is actually the more sympathetic and attractive character, exactly
because his actions aren't explained along some cooked textbook answers.

It's better than expected

Being Dutch, like the director Halina, I was very sceptical. A lot of
movies coming from Dutch directors revolve around sex and often
portrayed in a very explicit manner that doesn't always help the story.

Babygirl is different. It is provocative and explicit, in a good way
because it actually serves the storyline. There is a suspense to it,
platfullness and eroticism that is quite unique for contemporary movies.
It dares to be uncomfortable and challenge your beliefs on
relationships, sex, power dynamics.

I read a lot of people having a hard time with the fact that both
characters don't have to face a lot of consequences from their 'bad'
behaviour. I see this differently. At the end of the day they are both
grownups and the movie is not about exploring the me-too theme at all,
it is not ment to be moralistic and judge these characters. It's about
exploring female desire.

And I have to say both lead actors give stellar performances. That also
helps!

Good job Halina!

What was Nicole Kidman thinking?

Nicole Kidman plays the wealthy CEO of a revolutionary company
headquartered in the Big Apple which pioneered the use of robotics to
deliver products to customers. She was an honors graduate from Yale so
she's supposedly smart, and lives with her husband and daughter in a
suburban house worthy of her success.

But behind the facade her husband, who directs plays on Broadway, does
not sexually satisfy her, and if the part she's playing matches her age
in real life, she has a hyperactive libido for a woman approaching 60.
She also shoots her face full of Botox giving her a plastic look and her
stringy hair makes her look unkempt.

That's the background for this totally absurd tale of sexual depravity.
Her large company with offices in a midtown office tower hires a group
of interns with no defined purpose or roles. One of these interns who
stands physically head and shoulders above the others is an arrogant boy
about a third of her age with a permanent leer on his face who somehow
pegs her as sexually submissive, and while his smug insolence should
have resulted in his immediate dismissal, in this sick fantasy of sexual
domination she risks her career, her company and her family so he can
humiliate her through cringeworthy acts that show she is in need of
serious psychiatric help.

I don't know what Nicole Kidman was thinking when she took on this
project. I mean, it's not like she needed the money or the work. But
it's put an indelible stain on her impressive filmography, and frankly
after watching this display of pointless filth I felt like I needed a
shower.

A daring, hypnotic dive into desire and power

Babygirl is a provocative and visually captivating film that explores
female desire, power, and vulnerability with unapologetic honesty.
Nicole Kidman delivers a fearless performance as Romy, a successful CEO
whose emotional control unravels when she enters a taboo affair with her
young intern (Harris Dickinson). Under Halina Reijn's direction, the
story becomes an intense psychological dance between dominance and
surrender.

Midway through, I caught myself wondering when things would go wrong -
and that's part of the film's power. It keeps you on edge, aware that
the line between passion and destruction is getting thinner with every
scene. You can tell the director is Dutch: there's a raw directness and
emotional realism that cuts through the glamour. The music is also
perfectly chosen; it pulls you right into each moment, heightening the
tension and intimacy without ever feeling forced.

Visually lush, daringly honest, and emotionally complex, Babygirl isn't
comfortable viewing, but that's exactly what makes it unforgettable.

Makes nbo sense at all, and totally useless movie

I went into Babygirl with an open mind, but I honestly wish I hadn't
wasted my time. From the start, the acting is stiff and unconvincing,
making it nearly impossible to connect with any of the characters. The
dialogue feels unnatural, and the cast delivers their lines with all the
enthusiasm of a high school play gone wrong.

The story itself is a complete mess-filled with plot holes, nonsensical
character decisions, and scenes that feel thrown together without any
real direction. The pacing is all over the place, and just when you
think the movie might be going somewhere, it either drags on endlessly
or jumps to something completely irrelevant.

And don't even get me started on the editing! The transitions between
scenes are jarring, and the cinematography does nothing to help the
already weak storytelling. It feels like the film is trying to be deep
and emotional, but it ends up being unintentionally funny instead.

Overall, Babygirl is a frustrating watch. Bad acting, a nonsensical
plot, and poor execution make this a film to skip. If you're looking for
a movie that actually makes sense and has even half-decent performances,
look elsewhere.

A Problematic Movie Lacking Substance

I specifically made this IMDb account just to leave this review. This
was the worst film I have ever seen. And that was not due to the acting,
which was, to be fair, phenomenal from all members of the main cast. I
cannot fathom how someone would think this movie was in any way
feminist. This is one of the most sexist movies I have ever seen.

Neither lead characters take the dynamic that is portrayed seriously or
deal with it in a healthy way, only talking of safe words after
countless hookups. Romy, played by Nicole Kidman, never at one point
makes an effort to discuss or explore her desired dynamics with her
husband in an healthy way, and acts like a child who "can't get what she
wants" but actually never taking the effort to get it in a healthy way.
Samuel is even worse, displaying childish outbursts and unhealthy anger
management, which immediately made me uncomfortable, reminding me of an
abuser. It is at first played off as this freeing act where both people
get what they want and perhaps even heal in that way, but despite Samual
playing like he deeply understands this dynamic and powerplay, none of
his actions and behaviour actually reflect this, and so comes off as an
unsympathetic liar. I involuntarily gagged while in the cinema after the
milk scene, and it made me feel sick for hours afterwards. That a
supposedly powerful and wise woman that has issues with her body-image
like Romy is supposed to trust someone like that, put everything on the
line for a manchild that can't even communicate like a grown adult, is
incredibly unbelievable and frankly frustratingly stupid. In a way both
deserve each other, as they are both admittedly manipulative
never-thinking-with-anything-but-their-groan characters.

For those who are unfamiliar with these unflattering sex scenes on the
silver screen, it may appear progressive and innovative, but if you look
further you'll see there is little substance below the surface. Just
like a lot of contemporary Dutch media that is supposedly progressive,
this is shock-value after shock-value with no actual deeper thought or
emotional depth. A media that so often glorifies sex as this all-freeing
activity around which large parts of life should be centred, as if there
is no other way to be satisfied in life. A resolute fear of not taking
itself seriously enough has resulted in a reluctance to adding humorous
moments, and thus failing on adding moments to catch your breath or
making watching these movies even a smidge enjoyable. For all
transparency, I am also Dutch and a woman, but this supposed "national
pride" I've seen a lot of Dutch people that have been positive about
this movie display that did nothing to make this movie anything but 115
minute-long torture. If it wasn't that I went with this movie with a
friend I would've left 30 minutes in, only to realise after the movie
that she was thinking the same.

In keeping with a recent trend wherein longtime female A-listers make
boldly erotic provocative performances - as with Emma Stone in Poor
Things, and Demi Moore in The Substance - critics have, rightly or
wrongly, consistently lauded these performances with high acclaim.

Most obviously evocative of Fifty Shades of Grey - yet in my estimation
not nearly as cringeworthy - as well as Disclosure, Basic Instinct, The
Boy Next Door, and sharing plot points with the shamelessly low-brow
Lifetime movie Psycho Intern, the movie, thankfully, remains supremely
intelligent without going campy or murderous.

While others have suggested Nicole Kidman has made a career of
unsettling roles, I must say this one is perhaps the most daring and
unsettling - more so than we've ever seen Nicole Kidman before.

Rooted in eroticism, power dynamics, and in all likelihood childhood
traumas, the movie relies on a massive amount of nuance in every
interaction and conversation - both in the workplace and interpersonally
- and repeatedly begs the question... "Who actually has the power here?"

Antonio Banderas, who appears in the movie for good measure, early on
comes across as merely a prop and a generic unfulfilling husband. It is
only in the final act that his veteran acting chops are put to good use.

As the movie wound down to a conclusion, I did start to feel that there
could be no ending that could reasonably be satisfying. And, frankly, to
that point, one could make the argument that the movie did in fact end a
little too "neat" and convenient. But I won't let this takeaway from
Kidman's performance and the thought-provoking emotional conflicts
throughout.

We Watched Babygirl So You Don't Have To

So this was the first erotic thriller any of us had ever watched. None
of us really knew what we were getting into. We watched Babygirl at
home-just three friends hanging out: Winny, Willow, and Mimikyu. And...
well... this movie had high stakes scenes. If you know, you know.

Winny actually liked the concept in theory-he thought the idea had
potential and kept saying it could've been something cool if it was just
handled differently. Willow, on the other hand, was way into the vibe.
He was all in for the drama and the edgy stuff, like he was living for
the chaos. Mimikyu was more chill about it-she didn't have strong
expectations and just wanted a movie night with her friends. At first,
it started promising and we all thought we might be in for something
interesting.

But... yeah. The writing? Not great. The characters felt kinda flat and
a little off. Like, sometimes things would happen and we'd all just look
at each other like, "Wait, what was that?" There was too much focus on
the sexual tension and not enough on making us care about what was
actually happening. Which, yeah, we get it-that was kind of the point of
the movie-but still, it got old fast. Some of the scenes were just
awkward instead of intense, and not in a good way.

By the end, we were all kind of disappointed. It just didn't land. The
movie had all this potential to explore something deeper, but it leaned
too hard into the shock factor and left the rest hanging. Could've been
smarter, could've been more fun, could've been just better.

Would we watch another erotic thriller? Maybe. But next time, it better
have more than just that.

disappointing film with problematic morals

Babygirl is a film that, while perhaps aiming to be edgy or emotionally
raw, ultimately falls flat due to its troubling message and questionable
portrayal of morality. Rather than challenging societal issues in a
meaningful way, it seems to glorify toxic behavior and normalize
dynamics that should be critically examined-not accepted.

The characters, particularly the leads, make a series of choices that
are neither admirable nor redeemable, and the film does little to hold
them accountable. Instead, it presents these decisions as understandable
or even justified, which sends the wrong message-especially to younger
or more impressionable viewers.

What's most concerning is how the film skirts serious issues and instead
leans into sensationalism, using inappropriate relationships and
manipulative behavior as plot devices without offering any real
critique. It may try to present itself as gritty or authentic, but that
doesn't excuse the normalization of morally flawed conduct.

In short, Babygirl is not just a misfire in storytelling-it's a film
that promotes values we shouldn't be endorsing. Morality matters in
media, and this is one example where the line between artistic
expression and social responsibility feels irresponsibly blurred.

Nicole Kidman delivers an inspiring performance as the titular Babygirl,

these flaws, the film earns points for ambition and its strong lead
performance, but the overall experience falls short of its potential.
