Just a rip off from K√§rlek & Anarki (Love & Anarchy)

"Babygirl," directed by Halina Reijn and starring Nicole Kidman, has
been lauded as a provocative addition to the erotic thriller genre.
However, it's strikingly similar to Netflix's Swedish series "Love &
Anarchy" ("K√§rlek & Anarki"). Both narratives center on a high-powered
woman engaging in a clandestine, flirtatious relationship with a younger
male colleague, leading to personal and professional upheavals. In
"Babygirl," Kidman portrays Romy, a CEO entangled with her intern,
Samuel, exploring themes of power dynamics and forbidden desire.
Similarly, "Love & Anarchy" follows Sofie, a consultant who embarks on a
daring game with a young IT technician, challenging societal norms and
self-perception. The parallels in character development, plot
progression, and thematic exploration suggest that "Babygirl" is not as
original as it's presented. It's surprising that this resemblance hasn't
been widely discussed, raising questions about the film's originality
and the creative process behind its conception.

Halina Reijn's 'Babygirl': A Feminist Revolution in Erotic Cinema

Nicole Kidman delivers a fearless performance in Babygirl, a candid tale
of lust, power dynamics, and control. The film explores the complexities
of female sexuality and the disarray that arises when defining one's
needs. Halina Reijn's direction channels the spirit of classic erotic
thrillers like Unfaithful and 9¬Ω Weeks, but with an up-to-the-minute
corporate twist that is both humane and insightful.

Nicole Kidman is fearless in this brutally candid exploration of lust
and power

One of the many reasons that sex scenes in movies have faded as a
phenomenon is the omnipresence of pornography. When people can easily
click on their deepest kinks and favored objects of desire, who needs a
carefully staged R-rated "erotic" version?

As if to acknowledge this, Babygirl, a drama about a dangerous office
liaison written and directed by Halina Reijn (Bodies Bodies Bodies),
opens with a high-angle close-up of Nicole Kidman straddling an unseen
man, panting with pleasure. It looks and sounds like the kind of movie
sex scene that once would have been described as "hot." But as soon as
the coupling is over, and the man-Antonio Banderas, as Kidman's
husband-says "I love you," we see Kidman slip into another room (easy to
do in their spacious Manhattan apartment), where she lies on the floor
in front of her laptop and masturbates to a grungy piece of incest porn.

The irony here is that Kidman's character, Romy, is presented as a woman
who "has it all." She's the CEO of her own company-an e-commerce outfit
called Tensile Automation, akin to a next-level Amazon that promises
one-day delivery using automated logistics (i.e., robots run the entire
warehouse). She has a caring, supportive husband, who's a prominent New
York theater director, and two vibrant teenage daughters (Esther
McGregor and Vaughan Reilly). And she has a "healthy" sex life-but also
secret transgressive fantasies, which are what really get her off. In
other words, she has it all; she just doesn't have it all in one place.

Early on, we see Romy in the office, presenting mission-statement videos
for the company, where every upbeat word is market-tested, including a
reference to how "nurturing" the company is-despite its all-robot
premise effectively putting people out of work. Romy rationalizes it as
liberating people from menial jobs. This sly take on corporate culture
today connects directly to Romy's pent-up sexuality and the forbidden
office hookup about to ensnare her.

Romy, with her "friendly" professional demeanor and eyes glued to the
constant information stream of her phone, is the quintessential boss as
highly functional control freak. Underneath it all, she craves a kind of
sexuality that breaks apart that control. The implication of Babygirl is
that it isn't just Romy-it's a societal issue. We are increasingly
rooted in technology and corporate routines, where everything is
controlled, feeding a desire to break free.

Enter Samuel (Harris Dickinson), one of the company's new interns. The
young man who ignites Romy's fantasies is much younger-a work colleague
barely out of college. Had Babygirl been made 20 years ago, it might
have been conceived as a "cougar" fantasy, centered on animal magnetism.
Instead, Reijn crafts a far shrewder narrative.

The two meet when the interns are given a tour of Tensile's sprawling
lower Broadway office suite. During the introduction, Samuel asks Romy
an incredibly blunt question about the company's robot premise.
Dickinson, the gifted actor from The Iron Claw and Triangle of Sadness,
has a blunt-edged charm reminiscent of a young Austin Butler. Samuel's
message to Romy is clear: "I make the rules by breaking yours." Their
chemistry is not about attraction-it's about the thrill of
transgression. Every time Samuel sees Romy, he hits her with another
casually hostile negging remark. His "flirting" is an aggressive
assault, and that's precisely why she can't resist it.

Babygirl becomes a shrewdly honest and engaging depiction of a "wrong"
sadomasochistic affair. Unlike her previous film Bodies Bodies Bodies,
which leaned into satirical slasher pulp, Reijn here embraces a more
realistic tone. The film feels reminiscent of Fair Play but with the
emotional resonance of Unfaithful. Nicole Kidman's fearless performance
is at the core of what makes this movie work.

Straddling the identities of mother, boss, adulterer, and submissive,
Kidman's Romy embodies complexity, much like a walking mood ring. Her
character draws on a hidden truth-people in positions of power often
fantasize about submission. While prominent male executives have been
stereotypically linked to BDSM fantasies, we rarely see a corporate
woman portrayed in the same light. Babygirl turns the gender tables,
evoking comparisons to 9¬Ω Weeks as Samuel gradually breaks down Romy's
defenses. In one key scene, he sends her a glass of milk during
after-work drinks, declaring, "You're my baby girl." And when she drinks
it, she silently affirms, "Yes, I am."

In their hotel room meetings, Kidman oscillates between submission and
resistance, and the emotions playing across her face are nothing short
of astonishing. She lets us witness the erotic battle tearing Romy
apart. The true danger, however, isn't the S&M kink-it's the breaking of
every corporate rule governing workplace relationships. Samuel exploits
these corporate protocols, using them to seduce Romy. The fact that
she's risking her entire career by having an affair with an intern only
adds to the allure. Kidman's genius lies in portraying this recklessness
as utterly human-the desperate expression of a woman too
compartmentalized to reconcile the different parts of herself.

Does it all come crashing down? Babygirl follows a more conventional
trajectory in some aspects (including one memorable eye-candy moment,
where Samuel dances to George Michael's "Father Figure"). But one of the
film's strengths is avoiding the roller-coaster final act expected of an
"erotic thriller." Instead of moralizing in the vein of Fatal
Attraction, Reijn aims to liberate characters already busy punishing
themselves. The film takes unexpected turns, and that's because its
ambition goes beyond fueling the thriller-it seeks to authentically
depict women's erotic experiences in an age of control.

This movie is a must watch for anybody with a sophisticated sexual and

Babygirl" (2024) delves into the complex world of unconventional
relationships, challenging viewers to look beyond superficial judgments.
The film, directed by Halina Reijn and starring Nicole Kidman, explores
the dynamics of power and desire through the lens of a high-powered CEO
who engages in a risky affair with her younger intern.

At its core, "Babygirl" argues that those who do not share or understand
a particular kink often misjudge it, viewing it through a lens of moral
or societal norms. However, for those who experience and understand
these desires, the film illustrates how such relationships can serve
deeper emotional and psychological needs.

Nicole Kidman's fearless performance brings depth and authenticity to
her character's journey, making the film a thought-provoking exploration
of human nature. While the subject matter may be controversial,
"Babygirl" succeeds in sparking important conversations about acceptance
and understanding in modern relationships.

Overall, "Babygirl" is a bold and provocative film that encourages
viewers to question their preconceived notions and embrace the
complexity of human desire.

Title (Brazil): "Babygirl"

Disturbing and Disgusting in Every Way...

If you're looking for a film that epitomizes bad acting, a nonsensical
script, and an overindulgence in uncomfortable, borderline repulsive
sexual themes, Baby Girl is the perfect example. This so-called "sexual
drama" is nothing more than a confused mess trying to pass off shocking
content as meaningful storytelling. The movie also has a very disturbing
way of narrative structure, putting such awkward visuals back to back.
First and foremost, the acting is atrocious, I don't even want to
remember Nicole Kidman and Antonio Banderas has been a part of this
steaming pile of garbage. Their performances felt so forced, wooden, and
at times completely nonsensical. The dialogues are also so unnatural and
empty.

The movie is simply about a powerful business woman who has a sexual
paraphilia of submission but in a very ridiculous way. Instead of
delivering a compelling story, the actors stumble through a ridiculous
script that is more concerned with pushing boundaries than telling a
meaningful narrative. The movie is filled with one absurd scene after
another, each more unnecessary and outrageous than the last. The film
seems obsessed with including as many disturbing and tasteless elements
as possible: bizarre sexual games, uncomfortable and unconvincimg
age-gap relationship, and behavior that is completely out of place for
women of a certain age, power and reputation. Instead of being an
exploration of human desires, it just comes across as grotesque movie
that leads only to one final faked orgasm scene.

The way the film portrays women is another major issue. It glorifies
reckless behavior, promotes abuse under the guise of "empowerment," and
seems to celebrate decisions that go against basic moral and family
values. The concept of "women's power" here is distorted into something
unrecognizable, as the manager woman character engage in degrading acts
with an intern. Sex outside marriage and forgiveness is normalized to an
absurd degree, and worst of all, the couple supposedly learns their
lesson from this huge mess in the end.

The film throws in an unnecessary lesbian subplot, an underage sexual
theme and even a hint of animal abuse just for the sake of being "edgy".
And let's not forget all the disturbing relationships between co-workers
etc. The film goes all in on the trend of older women getting seduced by
younger men, pushing the boundaries of what is acceptable and turning
everything into a crude spectacle. The way the film revels in sexual
fantasies that are out of place and inappropriate makes it clear that
it's more about indulgence than storytelling. Fortunately we don't see
much of the nudity or obscenity, however the movie keeps hinting on
everything that can be considered as totally disgusting. It's clear the
director and the writer of this mess, Halina Reijn wanted controversy
over quality, just like her entire filmography based on similar themes.
In the end, Baby Girl is a a cinematic train wreck. It is not even
empowering for women, or thought-provoking, or even entertaining-just a
disturbing mess of bad decisions strung together by terrible acting and
a weak plot. If you're looking for a film with some depth and emotion,
avoid this at all costs.

Ridiculous Premise

Old Lady Does Stuff With Young Man

"Babygirl," directed by Halina Reijn and starring Nicole Kidman,
attempts to present itself as a provocative exploration of power
dynamics and forbidden desire. However, the film ultimately falls short,
delivering a narrative that is both unsettling and problematic.

The plot centers on Romy Mathis (Kidman), a high-powered CEO of a
robotics company, who embarks on a torrid affair with her much younger
intern, Samuel (Harris Dickinson). This relationship jeopardizes her
marriage to Jacob (Antonio Banderas) and her professional standing.
While the premise aims to subvert traditional gender roles, it instead
highlights a glaring double standard. If the genders were reversed-an
older male executive engaging in a sexual relationship with a young
female intern-the narrative would undoubtedly be criticized for its
predatory undertones. Yet, "Babygirl" seems to expect audiences to view
this dynamic as empowering and artistic.

Critics have noted the film's failure to provide depth to its characters
or their motivations. The narrative is described as "nothing more than a
stillbirth, devoid of character development and depth"

. The exploration of BDSM themes is superficial at best, lacking the
necessary nuance and understanding to portray such complex subject
matter responsibly.

Furthermore, the film's erotic elements are neither enticing nor
tasteful. One reviewer observed, "The sex wasn't sexy, but boring and
disturbing"

. This sentiment is echoed by others who found the intimate scenes
lacking in genuine chemistry or passion.

"Babygirl" also struggles with its portrayal of power dynamics. While it
attempts to flip the script by placing a woman in a position of
authority, it inadvertently reinforces problematic stereotypes. The film
fails to delve into the ethical implications of a superior-subordinate
relationship, glossing over the potential for coercion and exploitation.

So, to sum it up, "Babygirl" misses the mark on multiple fronts. Its
attempt to be a bold, erotic thriller is undermined by a lack of
self-awareness, character development, a superficial treatment of
complex themes, and a troubling double standard in its portrayal of
predatory relationships. Rather than being a thought-provoking piece, it
comes across as a misguided and uncomfortable viewing experience.

"Babygirl" - A Film Lost in Its Own Pretensions

It's hard to decide what's more frustrating about Babygirl: its empty
attempt to appear provocative or its complete lack of depth in handling
its own themes. Marketed as a psychological erotic thriller, the film
actually stumbles over its narrative indecision, delivering a
superficial, predictable, and often laughable experience. Nicole Kidman
tries her best to give credibility to the messy script, but even her
talent can't save a film that doesn't know whether it wants to be a
social critique, a psychological exploration, or just another recycled
forbidden affair fantasy. Harris Dickinson's character, for instance, is
so caricatured and exaggerated in his juvenile arrogance that he becomes
implausible and even comical. The chemistry between the protagonists is
nonexistent, making the supposed eroticism as cold and uncomfortable as
the scenes where the film tries to take itself seriously. Moreover,
Babygirl attempts to address female sexuality and power dynamics with a
depth that simply doesn't exist in the script. Instead of a
well-constructed reflection, we get forced dialogues, disconnected
scenes, and underdeveloped characters. The protagonist's affair with her
young lover happens so abruptly and unrealistically that it undermines
any sense of realism or emotional impact. To make matters worse, it
starts with a completely dysfunctional family that openly supports the
daughter's lesbian relationships, while the submissive cuckold husband
not only forgives but also continues to tolerate his career-obsessed,
cheating wife-who shamelessly performed oral sex on her sleazy
lover-trying to sell the idea that this mess of a relationship is
actually a family.

To make it even worse, Halina Reijn's direction seems more focused on
creating a stylish aesthetic than on developing a convincing narrative.
Some sequences, meant to convey tension and desire, turn out to be
unintentionally hilarious-like the infamous "dance" to Father Figure by
George Michael, a scene so cringe-inducing it borders on absurdity. The
ending, then, is a complete disaster. After two hours of a film that
tries to seem profound without ever really saying anything, we are given
a rushed, artificial, and meaningless conclusion. If Babygirl had any
chance of redeeming itself, it completely falls apart in the final
minutes. In the end, Babygirl is the perfect example of a film that
wants to be controversial but lacks the courage to do so. Its eroticism
is dull, its tension nonexistent, and its attempt at psychological
analysis is shallow. If Kidman weren't involved, this cinematic mess
wouldn't even be worth mentioning. Rating: 1/10 - A thriller with no
passion, a provocation without substance, and a total waste of talent.

10/10 - A movie about exploration of desire and vulnerability

Here's a raw, pure, and brutally honest film that stands out from the
rest. When Romy, played by Kidman, undresses, she embodies a woman
tormented by society's judgement. No matter how confident she seems in
her career, expressing her true desires proves to be a challenge. Over
time, she begins to uncover what she truly wants, allowing her inner
yearnings to finally surface. Yet, her shame resurfaces time and time
again.

What's remarkable is that the film never judges. It leaves it entirely
up to the viewer to decide what to think. The acting, at times, feels
almost awkward-far from perfect. But that's exactly what makes it so
authentic. In real life, wouldn't you feel just as lost in a similar
situation? That raw imperfection is what gives this film its power.

So real - so impressive

First, I just need to say, to all the people I spoke with before I saw
this movie who told me "This movie is not horny, not hot, not sexy, not
interesting, not good, should have gone straight to streaming, or, it
was so boring", we are not the same. If you don't find this movie
"horny", I honestly have no idea what could possibly capture on-screen
sexuality to you outside of straight-up pornography. If this is not a
"horny movie" to you, honestly, what is!? What were you expecting from
this movie? I am dying to understand. My only thought is that perhaps
people who don't understand the psychological basics of S&M don't
understand what's going on here???

That aside, I naturally came into Babygirl expecting something "mid" and
walked out extremely impressed by what I would consider a flawless film,
and definitely a standout in the history of film. Nicole Kidman
maintains her status as an absolute queen of delivering complex,
provocative characters in erotically charged films that always manage to
have just enough separation from one another, yet they are all fully
believable as separate fleshed-out individuals (Eyes Wide Shut, and
especially To Die For, come to mind first, the latter being one of my
favorite movies ever). Noting that, it is INSANELY IMPRESSIVE that
relatively new star Harris Dickinson (Triangle of Sadness, The Iron
Claw, etc) could get dropped into a movie this intense and FULLY hold
his own with the legend Kidman herself. Dickinson delivers one of the
most complex and bizarre characters this year, remaining wholly
unpredictable and mysterious in a very unique manner, even when the film
is through.

This movie is a grower, not a shower, and it absolutely gets better as
it goes, one scene after another, the tension slowly grows as it burns
hotter and hotter. As things unfold, it becomes more and more clear that
Dutch writer/director Halina Reijn has a deep understanding for people
with sexual personalities and sexual preferences that go beyond the
basic realm of "sex with the person you love". The film absolutely nails
the way it showcases the double-edged sword of debauchery: the utmost
thrill, and the utter plague.

If you need to see the good guys win in the end, Babygirl is not a movie
for you. There are no angels in this film. Trouble is lurking around
every corner. It's a film about inner psychological warfare, and it's
very real. The soundtrack is phenomenal. The pacing is ace. I honestly
can't believe this is by the same person who made Bodies Bodies Bodies -
while that movie was fun, it was also pretty dumb (consciously though, I
believe) - but this one is almost a spiritual opposite, bursting at the
seams with sincere human complexity. I was beyond impressed. Definitely
Top 10 of 2024.

An Intimate Exploration of Power, Desire, and Connection

Director Halina Reijn is known for her sharp psychological insights and
confrontational cinema. In Babygirl (2024), she delves deep into the
complexity of desire, power, and intimacy in relationships. With Nicole
Kidman in the lead role as Romy Mathis, a successful tech CEO, and
Harris Dickinson as her young intern Samuel, a story unfolds that is
both challenging and

Romy Mathis seemingly has the perfect life: a thriving company, a stable
marriage with Jacob (Antonio Banderas), and an apparent control over her
world. Yet, something fundamental is missing in her life: sexual
fulfillment and a deep sense of connection. When Samuel enters her life,
he opens a door to a forbidden and thrilling dynamic that unsettles her
entire self-image and relationship.

The film explores in a nuanced way the psychological and emotional
tension between power and vulnerability in relationships. This closely
aligns with the insights of renowned relationship therapist Esther
Perel, who argues that desire thrives in space, mystery, and a certain
degree of autonomy. Perel's work emphasizes how intimacy and eroticism
sometimes stand in contrast to the stability of long-term
relationships-a tension that is central to Babygirl.

Babygirl is not a typical romantic drama but an exploration of the
complex reality of human relationships. It is a film that raises
questions about love, sexuality, and the role of power within intimacy.
Much like in Esther Perel's books and lectures, it becomes clear that
desire is not only about what is present but, more importantly, about
what is missing. For those open to a profound, psychologically charged
cinematic experience, Babygirl is a must-watch.

A failure

Babygirl (2024) attempts to explore desire, power, and erotic tension,
but it fundamentally misrepresents the dynamics of sexual submission.
While Nicole Kidman delivers a polished performance as Romy, a powerful
executive drawn into a dangerous affair with a younger intern, the film
treats their relationship superficially, often sliding into
unintentionally humorous territory.

It would be better if we saw a dynamic relied on trust, communication
and respect as it is about erotic tension. Babygirl, however, frames
submission almost as a gag or plot device. Romy's supposed surrender to
the intern is exaggerated, stylized, and often absurd, portraying
moments of power exchange that are cartoonish rather than
psychologically believable. The film seems to confuse sexual submission
with (non-sexual) humiliation or whim-driven manipulation, turning
serious dynamics into spectacle. This misrepresentation undermines any
exploration of intimacy, leaving viewers unsure whether the film intends
to titillate, satirize, or simply shock.

Ultimately, the movie falters in its central theme. It loses credibility
and risks trivializing a nuanced aspect of human sexuality. What could
have been a dark, psychologically rich exploration of desire ends up
feeling stylized, exaggerated, and occasionally comical.

A Breath of Fresh Air

Brilliant! Beautiful performances. Skillfully exploring human desires,
morality, consent, flaws, ambition and power. Intellectually plotted
human sexuality and psychology..Setting traps all over the plot. Fresh
score!

It explores themes of power, sexuality, shame, and consent, and how
these dynamics manifest in the workplace. The film also examines how
women are treated in society, and how they are expected to behave... The
film also explores how Romy and Samuel explore and divulge their
boundaries as they confront ethical and moral dilemmas.

The movie may display the primary plot of the erotic thriller, but the
themes of the film are entirely rooted within Romy's personal growth and
eventual acceptance of her sexuality.

Almost Unwatchable

I cannot even begin to think what position this dull film has on women's
sexual lives. And in my opinion this film is not erotic at all; just the
opposite. We open with the sounds of an orgasm, and we end the film with
the same, and no spoilers but the three main characters move around in a
cage of limited desires. Nicole Kidman in one scene ferociously feels
trapped by her sexual fantasies, and clearly trapped too in a power
situation with a thuggish young man with a black dog and like a dog she

Banderas is a theatre director, and glimpses of his production of
Ibsen's ' Hedda Gabler ' echoed the feeling that these people were
trapped, and for those who do not know the play Hedda kills herself
because of her frustrated passions. I find this a clever touch, and the
production itself looked interesting. And yet again this film's scenario
is set against New York wealth which feeds itself into its own cruel
domination. Is the film condemning Kidman's fantasies, and the scenes
with Harris Dickinson's character's emotional and cruel games which she
agrees to, and blackmailed to accept, any sort of resolution in her need
for fulfilment ? I leave the question open as the whole film is a big
question mark about how much freedom women, and men really have.

Does not live up to the hype

Romy (Nicole Kidman), the head of a large company, accustomed to
managing people, becomes the plaything of young intern Samuel (Harris
Dickinson). The rules are simple: she obeys all his orders, and he keeps
her secret. But the passion that escapes outside the office threatens to
destroy them both.

I think the film is supposed to lay bare the inner turmoil of strong,
powerful women who have latent sexual fantasies. A younger man, a
dominant man, doing things she's never tried before all lead her down a
road that is dangerous to her family, yet exciting to her. It explores
the raw sexuality that women often don't admit to, preferring to embed
their sexuality in terms of love rather than want. That's what the film
is supposed to be about.

However what it is about is nothing more than soft pornography. The sex
scenes are supposed to say something, but there is no real dialogue that
explains in detail what the main character is going through. It's just a
woman exploring exciting sex with a younger man. There are hints of her
inner mind working, but nothing spoken about in detail that airs ideas
or raises questions about the theme. So the sex actually overtakes the
film and becomes the main part of it, but divorced from any reasoning as
to why. It also seems to suggest that if you pressure a woman enough she
will give in to your male fantasies, which I think is a dangerous road
to go down. She should have pursue this relationship willingly, rather
than to be seen to be pushed into it. (Although some people might
suggest this is normal behaviour) The acting is so-so, the camera work
is pretty poor a lot of the time, and sometimes it appears there's no
direction except what the actors 'feel' in the moment. I don't think
it's Nicole Kidman's best work, and Antonio Banderas is very average,
almost weak throughout. Esther McGregor is very new and inexperienced
unlike her older sister Clara who is amazing.

So all in all it is a forgettable film, which does not spark debate, and
does zero to further women's or men's issues. I gave it a 5.

A Shallow Story with an Unbelievable Relationship

Babygirl tries to be a deep emotional drama but ultimately ends up as a
shallow and unrealistic film. The storytelling is weak, prioritizing
controversial moments over meaningful character development. The
relationship between the two main characters is entirely unconvincing,
neither emotionally nor logically justified. The film seems more focused
on showcasing an unconventional romance rather than providing a solid
foundation for it.

One of the biggest weaknesses is the male lead's performance. He lacks
both charisma and emotional depth, making it difficult to connect with
his character. The chemistry between him and Nicole Kidman is almost
nonexistent, leaving their interactions feeling forced and unengaging.
While Kidman does her best to elevate her role, the weak script prevents
her efforts from fully paying off.

Overall, Babygirl had the potential to explore deeper emotional layers
but instead delivers a superficial story with underdeveloped characters.
It could have been a thought-provoking drama, but instead, it fails to
leave a lasting impression. If you're looking for a compelling and
authentic story, this film might not be the right choice.

bestever

Hat really carries this film are the two excellent central performances
from Nicole Kidman and Harris Dickinson. Without them, this film would
be entirely forgettable, particularly because this film doesn't really
break new ground in its genre and the plot is thin. Sophie Wilde and
Antonio Banderas are also good in their supporting roles. Kidman is
great in portraying a woman who wants to sink into her desires, but is
constantly conflicted in doing so.

The score, soundtrack, atmosphere, the costumes Kidman wears, and
cinematography all really elevate this film. The film feels very cold
and aloof, which is in keeping with our protagonist. As alluded to
earlier, the film's biggest issue is that the story is tenuous and not
really anything new. It's surprisingly tame for what it is. It almost
felt like the film was self-conscious and scared to really go there and
be prurient. But perhaps that was intentional, to mirror Romy's
reluctance to go there herself. While there is some nudity, it never
really feels sexy. Perhaps that was the director's intent though. While
sex scenes in erotic thrillers tend to be sexy, passionate, salacious,
almost fantastical, the sex scenes in this film feel very organic, and
even awkward at times. Between Romy and Samuel there are awkward
silences, confusions as to what to do next, insecurities about intimacy.
The result is that you feel like a fly on the wall. However, as a
viewer, that is both positive and negative. Positive because it feels
realistic, perhaps relatable. But negative because much of the film is
difficult to watch. What really would have elevated this film is
fleshing out Romy's past and her dark desires.

A nitpick I had with the film is regarding Samuel's tattoos. It felt
like he was a walking bad-boy stereotype; the tats felt a bit too
on-the-nose and obvious. Dickinson's presence alone was sufficient
enough to signal to the audience his dark, dominant interiority.
Dovetailing off of that point: while it was refreshing to see a power
dynamic in a film wherein the younger of the two parties has the power,
as it's typically portrayed as being the inverse, the abrupt jump from
new intern to a forbidden affair with his boss was jarring and
implausible, if we are to believe this film takes place in reality. But
the director's conceit here very well may be a heightened version of
reality, a fantasy.

That being said, the film is worth checking out, if only for the great
acting.

A flailing failure

I'm a fan of Nicole Kidman, but I lost some respect for her as an actor
after seeing this nonsensical waste of time. It was sold as erotic- it's
not. It plays with ideas and themes of sexuality without having a clue
of what it's actually trying to say about them. It felt like the writers
read Fifty Shades of Grey, came to some vague conclusions about women
being turned on by power struggles and domination, and tried to work
that notion into an edgy drama, without having a single insight to add
to it. This is especially apparent in the dialogue- whenever anyone has
a chance to explain what they're thinking, they just mumble and shout
incoherently. Really? A high-powered CEO who can't string a sentence
together? Who allows herself to be blackmailed by an equally
inarticulate 20-something? This is another problem with this movie-
there is simply too big of an age gap between these two "lovers". Nicole
looks great for a woman approaching sixty, it's true, but we all know
that's her age. I've been watching her in movies since I was a kid, how
could I not be aware of it? Watching a woman in her late fifties
crawling around on a floor at the behest of a guy well young enough to
be her son just feels tasteless and demeaning. As if this wasn't bad
enough, the film throws away the small amount of sexual currency it has
by having him literally threaten her with exposure if she doesn't do his
bidding. That's supposed to be sexy? I think not.

Antonio Banderas was a confusing casting choice as the husband, mainly
because he's about ten times hotter than the young guy, making her
choices even more baffling. He's wasted in this role. None of the actors
have any sexual chemistry, and this film absolutely required it.

Watching Babygirl made me think of 9 1/2 Weeks, a much older film which
explored these themes far more successfully. The sexual chemistry
between Kim Basinger and Mickey Rourke was electric. The power he had
over her was palpable, and it was easy to understand why she would allow
herself to get caught up in an affair that challenged her identity and
boundaries. My advice is skip this one and watch that instead.

This movie was awkward in every way - zero chemistry or sexual tension
between the leads, clumsy sex scenes, stilted dialogue, lack of charisma
or any other kind of saving grace really. I can see what kind of movie
it was aiming to be but it failed spectacularly, in every aspect. I will
give props to Antonio Banderas for delivering his lines with emotion.

A Bold and Unsettling Exploration of Power

Babygirl (2024), directed by Halina Reijn, is an intriguing and
unconventional film that challenges the audience with its unique
storytelling, strong performances, and striking visual style. It is a
movie that feels deeply psychological, relying on subtle interactions,
layered emotions, and an ever-present tension that keeps viewers engaged
from start to finish. Without revealing any spoilers, this review will
explore the film's strengths and the reasons it stands out as an
unexpectedly compelling cinematic experience.

A Visually Captivating Experience One of the first things that stands
out about Babygirl is its cinematography. The film has a sleek and
polished look, with carefully composed shots that create a strong sense
of atmosphere. The use of lighting and color palettes helps set the
mood, making certain moments feel intimate while others feel distant and
unsettling. Every frame seems intentional, and this attention to visual
storytelling enhances the overall impact of the film.

The setting also plays a crucial role in shaping the film's tone. The
environments feel cold and structured at times, mirroring the emotional
states of the characters. This artistic approach makes the movie not
just a story being told but an experience that the audience can feel.
The director's vision is clear, and it is executed with precision,
making every scene meaningful in its own way.

Strong Performances That Elevate the Story Nicole Kidman delivers an
outstanding performance in Babygirl, bringing depth and nuance to her
character. She portrays a powerful yet complex individual who is both
strong and vulnerable in different moments. Her ability to convey
emotions through subtle expressions and body language makes her
performance even more impactful. It is one of those roles that allow the
audience to connect with the character on a deeper level, even when her
decisions are not entirely predictable.

Harris Dickinson also gives a compelling performance, creating a
character who is intriguing and unpredictable. His presence on screen
adds to the tension of the film, and his interactions with Kidman's
character feel natural yet intense. The chemistry between the two leads
is undeniable, and it plays a major role in driving the film's narrative
forward.

What makes the performances stand out is how they avoid exaggeration.
Instead of relying on dramatic monologues or over-the-top expressions,
the actors deliver restrained and controlled performances, making their
characters feel real and layered.

A Story That Keeps You Thinking The narrative of Babygirl is not
straightforward, and that is part of what makes it so engaging. It is a
film that raises questions rather than providing simple answers. The
themes explored in the story revolve around power, human connection, and
emotional complexities, but they are presented in a way that allows
viewers to interpret them in different ways.

The screenplay is sharp and well-crafted, using dialogue efficiently
without unnecessary exposition. The film values silence just as much as
words, allowing certain moments to speak for themselves. This subtle
approach makes the audience pay closer attention to details, facial
expressions, and unspoken tensions.

While Babygirl does not follow a traditional storytelling structure, it
never feels confusing. The pacing is deliberate, allowing time for the
characters and themes to develop naturally. The film does not rush to
conclusions, and this slow buildup makes the key moments feel even more
impactful.

A Film That Stays With You One of the most impressive aspects of
Babygirl is its ability to linger in the viewer's mind long after the
credits roll. It is not a film that provides easy conclusions, but
rather one that encourages reflection and discussion. Different viewers
may walk away with different interpretations, and that is a sign of a
well-crafted movie.

At its core, Babygirl is a film about human emotions, choices, and the
complexities of relationships. It does not rely on unnecessary
sensationalism or exaggerated drama but instead presents its story with
a level of maturity and subtlety that is rare in mainstream films.

Final Thoughts Babygirl (2024) is an unexpectedly captivating film that
combines excellent performances, stunning cinematography, and a
thought-provoking story. It is a movie that does not conform to
traditional storytelling formulas, making it a refreshing and unique
experience. While its slow pace and ambiguous themes may not appeal to
everyone, those who appreciate films that challenge conventions and
invite deeper interpretation will find it rewarding.

For those looking for a well-acted, visually striking, and
intellectually engaging film, Babygirl is certainly worth watching. It
is a reminder that cinema can be both artistic and meaningful, offering
stories that go beyond simple entertainment and instead leave a lasting
impression.

Kidman not taking risks

I used to love Nicole Kidman, not because she was pretty and beautiful,
but because I found her to be a good actress. Now, for a long time, she
plays the same role over and over again: that of a privileged woman.
(Take Cate Blanchett for example, she is still taking risks, or at least
very different roles that require different skills as an actor).

I still like Antonio Banderas, because I think he can be believable as a
solid, kind husband, but could do equally well as a villain or a scary
cult leader or whatever role he chooses.

I think Harris Dickinson and Sophie Wilde were good, but replaceable.

My main complaint, other than Ms. Kidman playing the same character over
and over again, is that this movie lacked emotion, and most of it came
from the well-chosen soundtrack.

In the subgenres of erotic thriller and age-gap romance, the conflict
comes from the confusing nature of love, lust and choices and possible
sacrifices. (They made some pretty good ones in the 80s and 90s). Here,
love is the umpteenth thing that doesn't even come to mind, as they've
chosen to make it about the female-male/female power struggle, and so a
crucial element is missing.

I've found this movie cold and calculated, not at all erotic, no matter
how many body parts were shown or sex breathing faked.

To all the un-lovers!

This film is about a woman's fantasy. This is not about your sexual
fantasy, nor your own sex life.

So many people completely miss the point, which is that a powerful woman
is able to exercise her latent fantasy. She does this together with a
handsome young man that just happens to walk into her life.

All those remarks about Nicole Kidman having 'no class' are not only
sexist, they are deeply offending to those who believe that people (yes,
human beings regardless of their orientation or organ composition)
should be completely free in their decision making, as long as it
doesn't hurt others.

I've thoroughly enjoyed the film and as a white middle age guy I'm proud
to say that the theme and the way it was expressed deeply satisfied me.
If only because it apparently upset a number of 'conservative', pardon
me, extremists.

Babyboy

I decided to watch Baygirl to support Halina Reijn, a Dutch director I
admire as an Dutch actor. What started as a gesture of support quickly
turned into an impressive viewing experience that completely captivated
me.

Nicole Kidman's performance was absolutely breathtaking. I had never
seen her like this before: pure, open, vulnerable, and intimate. Her
chemistry with Harris was remarkable; every scene felt like a shifting
balance of power between them, moving from strength to vulnerability and
back again. This dynamic unfolded so naturally, always driven by love as
the central force.

Halina Reijn's directorial choices are nothing short of brilliant. She
captures the vulnerability and strength of a woman in a way that is both
raw and beautiful. Her approach felt genuine and personal, which made it
a deeply emotional and valuable experience for me as a viewer.

Baygirl exceeded my expectations and left me positively surprised. It's
an absolute must-watch-not just for fans of Halina Reijn or Nicole
Kidman, but for anyone who wants to be moved by a powerful film.

value in portraying them on the big screen. Betrayal is a reality in
life and a fantasy for some, but it never ends well in the real world.
It ends in upheaval, anger and deep pain. This may be a breakout role
for Nicole Kidman, but it degrades her as a performer in my mind.

Babygirl

Dutch writer/director Halina Reijn's new feature 'Babygirl' is an
exercise in boldness. The film is a fresh take on the age old story of
self-discovery and self-destruction.

In the movie Nicole Kidman plays Romy, a highly successful CEO of a
robotics company by day and sexual submissive by night. Despite having a
picture-perfect home life with a loving husband and two daughters, Romy
remains unseen and sexually unsatisfied until she meets an intern
(Samuel) at her company who sees a side of her that's she's been hiding
- her sexual identity.

Two older films come to mind when watching 'Babygirl' - Stanley
Kubrick's 'Eyes Wide Shut' and Adrian Lyne's 'Unfaithful'. All three
deal with infidelity and the razor's edge one walks when engaging in it.
What stands out in 'Babygirl' is the feral, masochistic nature of Romy
and Samuel's illicit encounters which leave Romy in equal parts
exhilarated, scared, embarrassed and liberated.

Reijn's film presents an unvarnished view into shifting power
differentials. The CEO has power over an intern just as much as a dom
has power over a sub. Romy the titan gives in to the commands of Samuel
the peon. Their initial encounters are awkward and uncomfortable both
for them and the audience. It's like watching two porcupines mate. The
fact that Romy is cheating on her husband, theater director Jacob
(played admirably by Antonio Banderas) is intriguing, but what she needs
for sexual fulfillment is even more so.

The performances are strong all around, but the film belongs to Kidman
whose brilliant portrayal is both brave and vulnerable. At 57, Kidman is
doing the best work of her career on TV and the big screen.

Reijn's direction is intimate, raw and unyielding. She pulls no punches
and lets scenes breathe until they become difficult to watch. The
cinematography is harsh and unfiltered, making the film feel more
realistic. I did have a problem with the bombastic score which, at
times, threatened to overwhelm the visuals.

All in all 'Babygirl' is a fascinatingly frank and thought-provoking
exploration of human sexuality that also turns the tables on workplace
sexual politics. Be prepared as this film earns its R rating, but it's
well worth the watch.

embrace a submissive role, contrasting with her usual dominant persona.
Enter Samuel, played by Harris Dickinson, a young intern who possesses

know. Everytime you think you are about to get a steamy scene, it cuts
to nothing. And here we go again to the abrupt transitions. I didn't
hate the movie but it wasn't great. I dont think ill be watching this
one again.

A One-Sided Portrait That Leaves Others in the Dark

Nicole Kidman delivers a bold, committed performance in Babygirl, a film
that attempts to explore female desire and personal rediscovery-but does
so at the cost of empathy, balance, and fairness.

What could have been a nuanced portrait of a fractured relationship
instead feels like a one-directional therapy session, where only one
partner's needs are treated as important. The woman's
dissatisfaction-emotional, sexual, existential-is placed at the center,
while her husband's quiet presence, loyalty, and emotional pain are
barely explored or respected.

The film leans hard into the idea that personal awakening justifies
betrayal and secrecy, but offers little reflection on the damage left in
its wake. Rather than giving equal space to both voices in a failing
marriage, the story places the burden entirely on one side, reducing the
other to a background figure-there, but barely heard.

While the themes of female empowerment and desire are worth exploring,
Babygirl falls into the trap of glorifying self-discovery without
accountability, ultimately leaving a sour aftertaste. It's a film that
wants to be brave, but instead comes across as tone-deaf to the
emotional realities of anyone who isn't the lead character.

The only honest review you'll get

I was surprised by how many bad reviews this film got. Watching it, I
thought it was pretty solid: good cast, decent story for what it is. And
it's an erotic movie, which you barely see from Hollywood anymore. So, I
was actually glad to see something in that genre again since it's been
pushed to the side for years.

But here's the thing-if you're going to make an erotic film, you can't
play it safe. You've got to really go for it. This movie never does. It
feels like it's holding back the whole time, like they were afraid to
actually show anything. For a film that's supposed to be erotic, it
barely even has nudity, let alone any real heat.

But here's the real problem: if you're going to make an erotic film,
make an erotic film. Don't half-ass it. Don't be afraid of what it is.
This movie wears the label but feels like it was censored halfway
through. No real nudity, no real heat. And without that, there's nothing
to connect to. There's no sexual charge, no tension. Nicole Kidman:
Phenomenal acting, no doubt. But from a physical standpoint? You're
looking at an emaciated frame with two half-moon breast implants that
offer zero sex appeal. It's like the body is just there, no allure, no
magnetism. It kills what the movie is supposed to be.

Same with Harris Dickinson. I can't really judge his sex appeal, but I
watched it with my girl, and her take was that he didn't do much for her
either. So, it feels like the movie missed the mark on both
sides-there's no real chemistry, no sensual pull.

In the end, Babygirl calls itself an erotic movie, but there's no
eroticism to be found. And that's why I believe I get why so many people
came away disappointed.

A New Age for Women in Film

I was drawn and intrigued by the idea of the storyline but the trailer
seemed to hint to what some reviews described the film as - a bit
shallow, not sexy, no substance or depth, so I hummed and hawed about
going to see it.

I'm so glad I did. The depth in the subtlety of Romy's predicament as it
unfolds rang so true and it was at times a very uncomfortable watch, but
without use of shock value - instead the much more artful technique of
absorbing the viewer.

The direction and story complemented uniquely well so it made sense when
I saw it was done by the same person. A woman. And it shows. To have a
story told that resonated so well with me for the first time ever shows
how underserved the freedom to tell women's stories is, and not just
some version that's been written for women with a load of female
stereotypes or expectations of what women are, including stemming from
aspects of internalised misogyny.

The only thing I felt could've been done better was the ending. It seems
Hollywood can't not have a hopeful ending, which didn't fit with the
overall stream of consciousness narrative vibe it had for me at that
point. It could've stopped at any point in her story and it still
would've been a story well told.

Zorro and Satine became...this?

I don't know if it was the current mood I was in, or maybe I was
expecting something different, but this movie is utterly boring! It has
very little new and fresh things to offer the audience, just another
story of a woman in management having an affair with a colleague which
has a lot of canine fetishes in the mix. I mean AB and NK were such good
actors with blockbuster movies behind their names, and then you get this
bland stuff. I just had to push through it and had to end the movie
three-quarter way because I just couldn't wait for anything exciting to
happen any longer! It's not even about the acting or the lack of nudity
for a so-called erotic theme, it's the storyline. It's too
straight-lined and slow...bleh.

A failed and crude attempt that doesn't go beyond clich√©

The film presents, on its surface, a bold and tense story about power,
desire, and ethical boundaries. This erotic thriller garnered attention
at the 2024 Venice Film Festival, earning Kidman the Best Actress award.
However, in its deeper layers, the film grapples with fundamental
difficulties in the interplay between form and content, identity and
persona, and ambiguity and explicitness, ultimately rendering it a
flawed work.

At the heart of the story is Romy Mathys (played by Nicole Kidman), a
woman at the apex of power in a modern high-tech company who, in her
personal life, desires submission. This duality, on the surface, is an
allegory for the contradictions of the modern subject: an individual who
celebrates their autonomy within the capitalist system yet privately
confronts a crisis of meaning, emptiness, and a desire to surrender to
another.

The film somewhat accurately depicts this paradox, but its philosophical
depth remains incomplete. In her interactions with Samuel, Romy
oscillates between dominance and submission, yet the film refrains from
a precise exploration of the nature of these desires. Is the desire for
submission a form of escape from the responsibility of the modern
subject? The film raises these questions but does not answer them; or
perhaps it lacks the courage to do so.

Furthermore, the relationship between power and desire in this film is
largely reduced to a visual and titillating display rather than an
internal exploration of the human psyche. This superficiality prevents
the film from becoming a truly existentialist or psychoanalytic work.

From a philosophical standpoint, the film aims to address themes such as
power, submission, and self-awareness in human relationships-themes that
could be referenced to the intellectual tradition of philosophers like
Michel Foucault and Simone de Beauvoir. In his analyses, Foucault speaks
of power as a fluid and bidirectional force that is constantly
reproduced in human interactions. The film ostensibly attempts to depict
this idea in the relationship between Romy (Kidman) and Samuel
(Dickinson), where power shifts from the manager to the subordinate and
then reverses again. However, this exploration quickly devolves into a
simplistic portrayal of dominance and submission, lacking any serious
reflection on ethical or existential complexities. Does Romy genuinely
seek a form of liberation from the oppressive structures of her life by
submitting to Samuel, or is this merely a superficial fantasy that
caters to her emotional and sexual needs? The film offers no answer and
does not even seem to take these questions seriously.

On the other hand, if we consider de Beauvoir's perspective in The
Second Sex, which emphasizes women's freedom and autonomy against
societal expectations, Romy's character is a disappointing paradox. She
is introduced as a powerful woman in the professional sphere, yet in her
personal realm, she falls into a clich√© of sexual submission as if it
were the only way to express her identity against life's pressures. This
contradiction could have led to a profound critique of gender roles in
modern society, but the film prefers to indulge in seductive visual
displays instead of reflection. Consequently, from a philosophical
standpoint, the film not only lacks depth but also seems to evade
difficult questions, settling for superficiality.

From a technical perspective, the film strives to create a minimalist,
cold, and controlled atmosphere that serves the overall theme of the
film-the suppression of emotions beneath the surface of modern urban
life. However, it suffers from several clear weaknesses that undermine
its ambitions.

Jasper Wolf's cinematography (which at times recalls the visual style of
Robert Bresson or Yorgos Lanthimos) creates a sense of distance, but in
many moments, it leads the audience not to contemplation but to
indifference. While visually pleasing at times, the cinematography often
falls into the clich√©s of the erotic thriller genre: soft and warm
lighting in intimate scenes, camera angles that emphasize bodies, and
excessive use of close-ups to convey emotional intensity. These choices,
although aesthetically acceptable, rarely serve the narrative and more
often convey the feeling of a glitzy music video than a coherent
cinematic work.

The film's editing is also one of its main weaknesses. The narrative
rhythm is inconsistent in many moments; long and drawn-out scenes of
interaction between Romy and Samuel are interspersed with abrupt cuts to
her family or professional life, disrupting the balance. This
incoherence prevents the audience from forming a deep connection with
the characters or their motivations. For example, the scenes involving
Romy's family life-with Antonio Banderas as her husband-are so brief and
superficial that they seem included merely to fill narrative gaps,
rather than to add a layer to the drama.

Halina Reijn's screenplay also suffers from serious weaknesses. The
dialogues are often clich√©-ridden and lack originality; especially in
moments intended to reveal the psychological depth of the characters,
they seem to be taken from a low-grade television drama. Samuel's
characterization is particularly weak-he is more of a narrative tool to
advance the story than a human being with his own motivations and
complexities. This imbalance in character development makes the
chemistry between Kidman and Dickinson, which is the film's main pillar,
seem artificial and unbelievable at times.

The acting, despite Kidman's relative brilliance, cannot save the film
from its downfall. Nicole Kidman's performance, while executed with a
certain control, suffers in some places from repetition and a lack of
gradual internal transformation. Samuel's character also remains on the
surface; in terms of drama, he is more of an "object of desire" than a
character with psychological complexity. Kidman creates moments of
honesty with the boldness and vulnerability she brings to the role, but
this effort is wasted against a screenplay that does not provide her
with sufficient depth. Dickinson, on the other hand, lacks the necessary
charisma or layers in the role of Samuel to justify his fatal
attraction-a problem that stems more from the directing and screenplay
than his acting.

The film tries to speak, with a modern and feminine perspective, about
power, desire, and the crisis of identity in an era of nihilism.
Ultimately, Babygirl is a flawed work; a film that promises a
philosophical crisis more than it delivers one. A film that stands on
the border between display and truth, but is afraid to make the final
crossing.

In the end, it is a film that has big ideas but falls prey to clich√©s
and superficiality in its execution. From a philosophical standpoint,
instead of a deep exploration of concepts like power and freedom, it
settles for simplistic and unreflective displays. Technically,
weaknesses in editing, screenplay, and character development prevent
even its visually appealing moments from creating a coherent or
impactful experience. This film might be acceptable as entertainment for
a general audience, but for a viewer seeking philosophical depth or
technical mastery, it remains disappointing and insufficient.

A hollow attempt at erotic thriller

Babygirl attempts to navigate the murky waters of power, desire, and

compelling erotic thriller. Directed by Halina Reijn, the film squanders
the star power of Nicole Kidman and Harris Dickinson, relying on
clich√©-ridden storytelling and shallow character development.

Kidman, as a high-powered CEO risking everything for a torrid affair
with her younger intern, does her best to bring nuance to a script that
fails to match her talents. Dickinson, while charismatic, is given
little to work with, and their chemistry feels forced rather than
provocative. Antonio Banderas' presence is underwhelming, reduced to a
supporting role that adds little to the narrative.

The film's attempts at exploring morality and power dynamics are muddled
by contrived plot twists and superficial dialogue. Instead of delivering
genuine tension or introspection, Babygirl relies on pseudo-provocative
scenes that feel more absurd than daring. The result is a film that
takes itself too seriously without offering meaningful insight or
entertainment.

promises.

difficult. The film lacks subtlety in character development and a more
sophisticated approach to its theme.

Nicole Kidman Shines In Provocative Exploration Of Power And Desire

Babygirl (2024), directed by Halina Reijn, is a compelling erotic
thriller that delves into the intricate dynamics of power, desire, and
self-discovery. Nicole Kidman delivers a standout performance as Romy
Mathis, a high-powered tech CEO who embarks on a transformative journey
that challenges her personal and professional boundaries.

The narrative is both provocative and thought-provoking, offering a
nuanced portrayal of a woman's quest for fulfillment beyond societal
expectations. Kidman's portrayal of Romy is both fearless and nuanced,
capturing the complexities of a character navigating uncharted emotional
territories. The film's exploration of themes such as control,
vulnerability, and the pursuit of authentic connection is both timely
and resonant.

Halina Reijn's direction brings a sharp and insightful perspective to
the story, balancing moments of tension with introspective depth. The
supporting cast, including Harris Dickinson and Antonio Banderas,
provide strong performances that complement Kidman's lead role.

Babygirl is a bold cinematic experience that challenges viewers to
reflect on the complexities of human desire and the often-blurred lines
between power and vulnerability. It's a film that lingers in the mind,
prompting discussions about identity, autonomy, and the lengths one will
go to find personal satisfaction.

Wannabe art

Movies today have become unbearably dark, joyless, and self-absorbed and
Babygirl is the perfect example of everything that's wrong with modern
"art cinema."

There's absolutely no chemistry between the leads, no passion, no
genuine emotion. It's supposed to be about desire, but it feels
completely lifeless. Every scene is cold, distant, and uncomfortable not
because it's deep, but because it's empty.

It's obvious the director wanted to "deconstruct lust" or make some big
psychological statement about power and loneliness, but the result is
just pretentious nonsense. Instead of emotion, we get awkward silence
and meaningless stares. Instead of intensity, we get boredom.

You don't leave this film thinking you leave it drained. And the worst
part is, it thinks it's clever for making you feel miserable. But making
your audience feel terrible isn't a sign of genius, it's a sign that
you've lost touch with what storytelling is supposed to do.

Cinema used to move people, make them dream, laugh, cry, feel alive. Now
it's just one long therapy session filmed in slow motion. People are
slowly getting tired of all this gloom, and thankfully, it can't last
forever.

Babygirl is not bold or profound. It's just another empty, soulless
movie pretending to be art.

A solidly entertaining modern day erotic thriller

Babygirl promised so much and for the most part it delivers on this, but
I can't escape the feeling that it held back slightly.

Not a day goes by where I don't see tweets claiming (entirely
incorrectly) that sex scenes ruin movies and sex scenes are unnecessary.
I'm not sure what is sparking this puritanical sentimentality but I'm
glad that films like Babygirl are being made to hopefully put a dent in
this misguided narrative. In this film sex is a key player and it drives
the plot and allows us to explore the characters in great detail. As a
sexual cat and mouse game ensues between the two leads, it explores
interesting notions of power, control, and pleasure.

The cat and mouse game in question is between high flying corporate CEO
Romy (Nicole Kidman), and cocky intern Samuel (Harris Dickinson). As the
former becomes increasingly curious and drawn in by the latter, they
become intertwined in a sexual power play that makes for a most
interesting watch.

As mentioned earlier, I do think the film could have gone a bit further.
It felt like it was still a little bit tame and restrained and on a
leash, and it could have benefitted from some more ambitious ideas.

Still, this is not a major draw back. In today's climate of film it
still feels relatively unique and is thoroughly entertaining. The
performances from Kidman and Dickinson are convincing and absorbing, and
the whole thing is wrapped up and presented in a stylish package.

So while this film might not get you too hot under the collar, it
certainly delivers as an erotic thriller and is thoroughly entertaining
and engaging.

Hardly Watchable

The premise of Babygirl feels too thin to sustain a full feature. The
story sets up an intriguing dynamic between power, desire, and control,
but it never really expands beyond its initial hook. For a film that
markets itself as a bold and provocative thriller, it comes across as a
little undercooked.

The casting also feels slightly off. Nicole Kidman is a phenomenal
actress and she certainly gives the role everything she can, but
physically and emotionally, she doesn't quite fit the part the way the
film seems to require. Her performance shows effort and flashes of
brilliance, yet the intended seductiveness doesn't fully land. Her
co-star Harris Dickinson has moments of intensity, but their chemistry
doesn't always feel convincing, which weakens the central relationship
the movie depends on.

Visually, the film looks polished and stylish, and the direction has
confidence. Still, style can't fully make up for the lack of depth in
the writing or the uneven casting choices. The result is a movie that's
watchable and at times engaging, but ultimately unsatisfying.

Babygirl isn't terrible, but it isn't especially good either-it's a
glossy thriller with strong performances trapped inside a story that
doesn't give them enough room to breathe.

Instinct on full display

Can anyone doubt that Nicole Kidman is one of the world's great
actresses? I certainly don't. What other actress of her generation could
so convincingly play a high-powered married mom/tech CEO who overcomes
lifelong sexual self-repression via a cunning, soft-spoken male intern
half her age who at once she cannot respect and yet cannot resist?
There's Julianne Moore, for sure. Likewise Hilary Swank and Charlize
Theron. Possibly Rachel McAdams and Emily Blunt. But Miss Kidman
delivers here in a way that perhaps even these actresses might not be
able to equal. Guided by the sensitive direction of Dutch native Halina
Reijn, Kidman puts on full display the many contradictions of feminism,
not to mention the impossibility of separating sexual desire and power.
And if she's playing her real self to an extent, well..so what?

"Babygirl" has its antecedents -- "Belle du Jour," "Basic Instinct,"
"Fatal Attraction" and Kidman's own turn in Kubrick's "Eyes Wide Shut."
But this film goes deeper emotionally. Even in subdued scenes, the
dramatic tension is unyielding. Our better instincts tell us from the
start of the affair that her character is not going to leave her husband
and two daughters, and run off with a brash, shallow, archetype Bad Boy,
and a highly invasive species at that. The larger point is that women,
contrary to what they may say outwardly, don't want a Nice Guy for a
partner. Is this instinct rational? Fair? No and no. It's just life.
Yes, even feminists on occasion crave submission, even in ways that
render her helpless and even abused. She's not getting that feeling from
her husband, superbly played by an increasingly preturbed Antonio
Banderas. Like it or not, BDSM fulfills a need for many people even as
it risks paying with fire.

I won't give away the story line, except to say that the movie has an
appropriately satisfying ending. Kidman's character ultimately doesn't
deny her animalistic, baby-like side; she simply transfers it to where
it matters. Go see "Babygirl" if you haven't already. And if you
haven't, crawl.

For me the absolute pinnacle of the Erotic Thriller sub genre is Belle
De Jour and The Secretary. On seeing the trailer for babygirl I had high
hopes that it may be in the same vain as those aforementioned films.
Unfortunately however it has more in common with the likes of Fifty
Shades.

Romy (Nicole Kidman) is the CEO of a package delivery company, think
along the lines of Amazon. She has a loving husband, two daughters and a
thirst to be told what to do sexually. Her husband is unable to tend to
her desires therefore when a new intern with a skill hand for control
starts at her company she drops to her knees.

We often hear it said that men in positions of power enjoy being
sexually dominated as it's the one part of their life where they can
truly give up control. This film tries to turn the tables by having a
powerful women giving up her control for sexual pleasure. Interesting
concept however it's poorly explored and ultimately tries to say that a
women in that position would do exactly the same as a man. That is in
the sense of taking advantage of their position of power to get what
they want. That being said you have to ask yourself what's the point of
the film?

Romy is said to have developed an interest for kink at an early age
perhaps while she was growing up amongst cults. The film however never
really explores the reasoning behind her fantasies. They're instead
explained through just a few lines of dialogue. I can't help but feel
like the film as a whole would have been more interesting had it delved
more into her past rather than solely focusing on her present dilemma.

As for the dilemma at the heart of this film, it all revolves around if
the truth will ever come out and will she loose everything in the
process. Despite this risk being what turns Romy on it failed to turn me
on and ultimately I was left disappointed.

Flat, ineffective erotic adventure

STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * Awful

Romy (Nicole Kidman) is the high powered CEO of a successful New York
tech firm, and has a decent home life, married to theatre director Jacob
(Antonio Banderas) with angsty daughters Isobel (Esther McGregor) and
Nora (Vaughan Riley.) But inside lurks a deep, tormented emptiness, that
comes to the fore when she meets Samuel (Harris Dickinson), with whom
she begins a torrid affair based on domination and control, that comes
to have a devastating impact on everything she holds dear.

In what seem to be more sensitive, volatile times in theatre and
culture, the 'erotic thriller' or 'erotic drama', seems to come around
much more sparingly (with the exception of The Fifty Shades series.)
They were a staple of the 80's and 90's, with films like 1981's Body
Heat, and the classic Basic Instinct in the early 1990's. Here,
writer/director Halina Reijn delivers what is, at the very least, a
daring piece (aren't they all?) that explores 'forbidden fantasies', but
the result is not that satisfying.

Reijn, an accomplished actress who seems to have moved into directing,
has assembled an all star cast, from veterans Kidman and Banderas, to
relative newcomers, most notably Dickinson, who does at least project a
simmering intensity in his role as the irresistible tempter. It also
benefits from an unsettling, shuffling score, with a neat soundtrack
(most notably, George Michael's Father Figure, in an erotically charged
scene.) The problem is, there's just not enough depth or development
invested in any of these characters to get us to care sufficiently about
any of them, or the outcome of their plights. Making the near two hour
runtime something of a chore.

In a time where sex serves as more of a currency than ever due to the
advent of the internet, erotically themed films still hold some
pervasive interest. Sadly, Babygirl just lures you in and bores you
silly. **

Babygirl

Rich and successful, company CEO Romy Mathis (Nicole Kidman) is happily
married to Jacob (Antonio Banderas) with two teen daughters. One day she
starts to have a passionate affair with a new young intern, Samuel
(Harris Dickinson) who provides her with the passion and danger that
hubbie no longer is. Things inevitably get tricky when Romy insists that
Samuel stays out of her private life. He thought, turning the affair to
his advantage starts to blackmail her and will talk to people in the
company if she doesn't do what he asks. The passion continues; she likes
it, she doesn't like it.

Whilst Kidman gives a strong, convincing performance here, the film
stands or falls on whether it is believable and frankly it isn't, either
on the relationship or the Corporate level.

I don't doubt that there are people out there who have wild passionate
corporate affairs involving drinking from saucers of milk with arrogant
idiots, but I wasn't sold on the idea here nor on the notion that a CEO
is in acute peril of losing their job because of they sleep with legal
age interns. Part of this may be to do with company rules on different
sides of the pond - in the UK, I doubt this sort of thing wouldn't
attract that much attention. Clearly this wants to be edgy and to join
the Hollywood gloss that is the Fatal Attraction / Basic Instinct /
Indecent Proposal etc set but despite Kidman, it doesn't really work and
in fact I found it rather silly and dull.

Babygirl

Behind the perfect career and family image the CEO Romy is hiding lots
of skeletons in the closet. After meeting and get to know the young
intern in her company she realized that finally she met someone who can
fulfill all of her deepest darkest masochistic desires. Of course it has
something to do with the childhood trauma and the whole thing was
portrayed very well in the movie. I also really like the way the movie
has developed because in the middle of it l almost thought that I was
watching some BS. But if you are in the middle of deciding whether to
watch it or not then just give it a chance and watch till the end.

It's absolutely not fair to compare it to "50 Shades of Grey" because
"Babygir!" has more substance, lots of things at stake, risks, deeper
meanings and you're not watching p*rn... When it comes to acting, Nicole
obvi was amazing. I just wanna mention that sometimes Harris D. Was "bad
at it" at least in my opinion... Idk, sometimes for me it just felt hard
to believe him (acting wise), like he wasn't trying hard enough, but
maybe it's just me.

It could have been good with a 'real' older woman

On paper, the premise had promise: an older woman dominated by a man in
his twenties. Awkward? Yes. But at least a departure from the usual
tropes. I imagined a story that leaned into the real power of age - a
woman with intelligence, maturity, and lived wisdom undone by raw
desire, her composure slipping, her dominance tested. That could have
been electric.

Instead, what we got was a hollow performance of insecurity. Nicole
Kidman has, tragically, become unrecognisable - her face a battlefield
of Botox, fillers, and reconstruction that erase the very tool of her
craft: expression. Rather than embodying an older woman's undeniable
allure and authority, she came across as desperate, diminished, and
cringeworthy.

The film itself lurched into clich√©, recycling unoriginal scenes with a
pornographic undertone so heavy-handed it collapsed under its own
tackiness. What might have been a bold exploration of female sexuality
and agency in later life was reduced to a hollow pantomime of lust.

Older women do not lose their power - they refine it. This film couldn't
even imagine that truth, and in the end, neither could Kidman.

Baffling

Surprisingly unsexy, given the subject matter.

nothing believable about their interactions, getting together, etc.

Even the musical choices throughout seemed out of place.

And sorry, but Nicole Kidman's face is such a distraction to me in
everything I watch her in these days.

Babygirl's down on all fours........

It just occurred to me that seeing Nicole Kidman acting like a dog on
all fours and drinking milk from a dish like a cat is kind of
humiliating, not what I would have expected from the likes of Nicole
Kidman.....

Babygirl is a confusing game of attraction, sexual fantasies and
fetishes between Romy and Samuel. It is an awkward relationship and is
never really clear who started it. It leaves you wondering what is
really going on the whole time. They seem to be playing a game exploring
certain roles, but it isn't clear who initiated it. It could be Romy,
not being satisfied at home and seeing an opportunity to explore her
deep sexual desires and fantasies with a young intern, pays Samuel to
help her explore those fantasies. Or it could be Samuel, seeing an
opportunity to take advantage of Romy's interest in him and move himself
up the company ladder.

Or is it Jacob? I find it hard to believe that for nineteen years, Jacob
didn't realize that his wife and sexual partner was not really fulfilled
and living a lie sexually. It seemed odd that Samuel would show up
unexpectedly at the house twice and Jacob just didn't appear that
surprised. And the fight that Jacob and Samuel have just didn't seem
that intense to me, it seemed staged. Jacob is a Theater Director and
stages plays and works with actors. It is possible that Jacob staged the
whole scenario to give his wife a controlled affair to explore her
fantasies with someone Jacob trusted to keep their marriage together.

Or was the whole affair staged by Esme who knew Romy and concocted a
scheme using Samuel to move herself up the corporate ladder? You could
go in any direction with those theories, but it did seem as though Esme
approaching Romy to, in essence, blackmail her for a better position at
the company was only after Samuel told her about their affair. That kind
of rules out Esme having orchestrated the affair.

Whichever way the plot was intended, it does come across as very
awkward. I didn't really feel any great chemistry between Nicole Kidman
and Harris Dickinson, either because there wasn't any or the whole
affair was staged to begin with. I have seen Nicole in better sensual
erotic movies with more chemistry and feeling. Dead Calm, Birthday Girl
and Eyes Wide Shut come to mind. Babygirl also reminds me of Unfaithful
with Diane Lane and Richard Gere, although I think Unfaithful is a way
better movie.

So to wrap it up, for me it was just ok. The sensuality and fetishes
were a bit over the top, I get they were exploring the power and
submission thing but it just didn't feel that real to me. Like a badly
staged play. I didn't think much of Harris' Dickinson's acting but then
I haven't seen him in anything else so perhaps it was just the
awkwardness of the role in this movie. So yeah, meh........
