Babygirl review

Office Rock

The premise here is one of a rather prosaic flavor, in that it involves
a common office romance, a situation that undoubtedly occurs with
regularity throughout workplaces all across America, if not the world.
The cinematic components that would differentiate this presentation as
compelling vis-a-vis typical similar stories is the lure of the big name
stars involved, which would also reasonably create associated
expectations of quality writing and overall direction. Unfortunately, no
such developments are on display. The complicating twist to this
particular tale is the aspect of the gender-sex-power factors that could
potentially make for complex and interesting relationships, but don't
hold out hope though because it's not gonna happen. There's an attempt
at a sort of mildly kinky sensuous scenario that mostly seems
gratuitous, or even pointless. Trying to figure out the ultimate point
or overall sensibility of this movie may prove baffling. Meanwhile the
soundtrack echoes and reinforces the cheesiness of the production, thus
at least proving cohesive. Christmas tree interiors with Kidman are
reminiscent of " Eyes Wide Shut " yet exist simply as decor for randomly
uninteresting characters wandering around spewing melodramatic dialog.
Kidman's Romy as a sexually frustrated power figure never gets the
benefit of having her psycho-sexual motives examined with any depth or
insight, which could have been the force that propelled this narrative
with conviction, instead of being a show of silly superficiality.

Compelling watch

Critically, "Babygirl" holds a 76% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes,
with the consensus noting the memorable chemistry between Kidman and
Dickinson, and Reijn's direction keeping the narrative provocative yet
tasteful.

However, audience reactions have been more divided, with a 48% audience
score on Rotten Tomatoes, indicating mixed feelings about the film's
content and execution.

Notably, Kidman's performance has been widely praised, with Time
magazine highlighting it as one of the finest of her career, capturing
both vulnerability and subdued emotion.

The New York Post also commended the intense chemistry between the leads
and the film's exploration of workplace taboos.

In summary, "Babygirl" offers a though provoking narrative with strong
performances, especially from Kidman. While critics have generally
responded positively, audiences have been more polarized. If you
appreciate films that explore complex themes and character dynamics,
"Babygirl" might be a compelling watch.

Refuses to go anywhere interesting

'Babygirl' is a an extremely disappointing directorial follow up to
'Bodies Bodies Bodies' from Halina Reijn. They're obviously very
different films, however all the competency that was shown in that film
is completely lacking here.

I can't get over how unimaginably safe this movie is. Everything is shot
in the least daring way possible. And the story refuses to go anywhere
audacious or take any chances at all. There's a quite brilliant review
on Letterboxd that says: "I've watched actual porn with more compelling
plotlines." And I couldn't agree more.

Worst of all is the complete lack of chemistry between the two leads. I
understand it wasn't entirely about "chemistry" and she was searching
for something else. But surely some chemistry wouldn't have hurt.
Compare this to 'Unfaithful' where the steam was almost coming through
the screen every time they were together, and that was why that film
worked so well and this one didn't at all.

This is just a long two hours of nothingness, and not a film I would
recommend. 4/10.

A study in power dynamics in personal and professional relationships

The first half of BG is wonderfully made. The acting is superb, the
writing is nuanced and it is wonderfully shot and photographed.

After the first hour the movie starts to realise that it needs to finish
to appease current 'modern standards and audiences' and it proceeds to
make a weak husband stay loyal, a strong CEO become blackmailed, the
same strong CEO reject her boss and yet submit to her underling, etc,
etc.

The movie skirts around these issues without ever dealing with them in
any detail, leaving the audience to fill in the blanks.

How did Kidmans character come to be as she is? We are never told.

It ends as a confused unsatisfying mess. The fight between lover and
husband was a real low point. It could have been a study in the power
dynamics of couples at work. It should have stayed with the themes of
the first half.

Sex and Power

Babygirl is wild, and Nicole does a good job of acting erotic. I'm not
surprised with her in the role, but the story and plot need to be
further developed.

The story line really isn't believable. A woman in the 21st century
wouldn't be married to a man for 19 years and have no orgasm. The lover
guy is miscast, Harris Dickerson. There is no chemistry between him and
Nicole. The husband Antonio Banderas is sexier than him. There is
nothing about the lover's appearance or conversation that would make an
audience believe and understand why Nicole is allowing him to dominate
her. The role playing dialogue is weak. Nicole's acting just saves the
scene. Why would she risk her career to be with him?
Disappointed

Ironically safe.

This opens with Nicole Kidman pretending to orgasm while having sex with
Antonio Banderas, before rushing off to watch porn. Sadly that sets the
base tone of what's to come, so to speak. They are Romy and Jacob. Jacob
being largely redundant in the story as you might've guessed. This is
Romy's world, one in which she runs a warehouse robotics company,
juggled with modern day motherhood. She's in charge, but she's hiding
something. A secret craving, one that's brought out by new intern Samuel
(Harris Dickinson). He's brashly confident and sees through Romy's
powerful controlled facade, but he's more of a creepy stalker than eager
intern. It's all rather implausible, troubling and feels a bit sterile,
but mostly it's just awkward viewing and a little infuriating. Kidman is
very good though and I have to admit, Dickinson is pretty magnetic. He
was great in Scrapper (2023) and even better here. I still kinda hate
this though. Romy wants to be dominated. Samuel wants to dominate her.
The affair then should work, but it's difficult to make stuff like this
work on screen without being potentially problematic. It's not easy to

to push buttons though, you'd better be sure you're bloody good at it.
This though, although edgy on the surface quickly turns into a run of
the mill thriller as Romy's secret life threatens to unravel her
personal and professional one. That might sound an exciting narrative,

been done with it and I'm sure there's an audience for this, but I don't
think I'm it.

story about resilience and growth.

When Star Power Cannot Compensate for Thin Storytelling

Babygirl, directed by Halina Reijn and starring Nicole Kidman, has been
touted as a daring erotic thriller exploring female desire and power.
Yet, beneath the glossy surface, the film struggles with fundamental
cinematic flaws that prevent it from delivering a compelling experience.

1. Lack of Psychological Depth

One of the most glaring issues is the absence of psychological
background for the main characters. Romy (Nicole Kidman) and Samuel
(Harris Dickinson) are reduced to archetypes-CEO and young
intern-without any convincing motivations, fears, or inner conflicts.
The audience is never given insight into their histories or why they
make the choices they do. As a result, their actions feel mechanical,
and the tension that could arise from authentic emotional stakes is
entirely missing.

2. Absence of Chemistry

Despite being central to the narrative, the relationship between Kidman
and Dickinson feels empty. There is no palpable chemistry; their erotic
encounters, which should be charged with intimacy and vulnerability,
instead feel staged and performative. Kidman's commitment to the erotic
scenes appears restrained, while Dickinson's performance fails to convey
any real desire or pleasure, leaving the viewer uninvested in their
interactions. A film that relies so heavily on sexual tension cannot
afford such disconnection between its leads.

3. Storytelling Deficiencies

Babygirl suffers from an underdeveloped plot. Beyond the surface-level
affair, there is no narrative propulsion or meaningful exploration of
the characters' journey. Key moments that should reveal growth or
consequence pass without impact, creating a story that is more a
sequence of events than a cohesive arc. The lack of narrative depth
makes the film feel superficial and unengaging.

4. Star Power vs. Substance

Nicole Kidman's iconic presence is undeniable, yet her star power alone
cannot elevate a film that lacks substance. The movie seems to lean
heavily on her celebrity status, as if her name alone could carry the
weight of the story. Unfortunately, audiences are left questioning
whether Babygirl would have been made at all if not for Kidman's
involvement. A powerful actress deserves material that challenges her,
not a hollow vehicle that underutilizes her talent.

Conclusion

While Babygirl markets itself as a provocative exploration of desire, it
ultimately falls short. Thin characterization, absent chemistry, and a
lack of meaningful storytelling make the film more style than substance.
Nicole Kidman delivers her signature presence, but it is insufficient to
rescue a movie that feels superfluous and undercooked. For a film
centered on erotic tension and emotional complexity, the absence of both
renders Babygirl an underwhelming experience.

Beautifully Shot but Deeply Flawed - A Frustrating Experience

Babygirl is a beautifully shot film that ultimately stumbles under the
weight of its own narrative inconsistencies and poorly developed
characters. Although there are some remarkable elements, they are
overshadowed by storytelling decisions that strain believability and
emotional engagement.

Visually, the film is stunning. The cinematography captures breathtaking
locations and atmospheric scenery, creating a vivid and sensual mood
that immediately pulls the viewer in. The "sexually charged" moments
between Romy (Nicole Kidman) and Samuel (Harris Dickinson) are among the
film's most compelling sequences. When isolated from the broader plot,
these scenes feel raw, authentic, and emotionally credible. They offer a
glimpse into what Babygirl could have been: a daring exploration of
forbidden desires. Special credit goes to Kidman for taking such risks
with her role-it's clear she put herself on the line, and her
performance is fearless.

However, when viewed within the context of the full story, these
strengths become disconnected. Romy's character arc quickly descends
into implausibility. Her reckless behavior-jeopardizing her career,
family, and reputation for a relationship that feels shallow and
manipulative-strains credulity. It's difficult to reconcile her supposed
status as a successful CEO with the naive, impulsive choices she makes.
The psychological motivation behind her actions remains frustratingly
underdeveloped, and as a result, Romy loses the audience's sympathy
about halfway through the film.

Samuel, portrayed by Harris Dickinson, is equally problematic. His
character is mostly a caricature of arrogance and selfishness, rarely
offering any real depth. Although there are brief glimpses of
vulnerability, they come too late and too inconsistently to make him a
truly compelling figure.

The supporting characters further diminish the film's credibility.
Sophie Wilde's portrayal of Esme, Romy's feminist secretary, feels
painfully forced and inorganic. Rather than serving as a natural part of
the story, her character comes across as a political statement awkwardly
inserted into the plot. Many reviewers noted-and I agree-that her
presence feels more like a lecture than authentic characterization. As
someone with real-world experience navigating similar issues, I found
this portrayal unrealistic and frustratingly heavy-handed.

Other reviewers have pointed out that while Babygirl aims to explore
complex themes of power, desire, and agency, it often falls into clich√©s
and shallow archetypes. Like many of them, I felt that the film wanted
to provoke but lacked the narrative finesse to justify its boldness. The
emotional beats don't land because the characters' decisions feel less
like the result of inner conflict and more like clumsy plot devices.

Despite its gorgeous cinematography, atmospheric tension, and Nicole
Kidman's brave performance, Babygirl ultimately collapses under the
weight of its contrived story, unbelievable character arcs, and forced
social commentary. While it has moments of interest and even brilliance
in isolation, as a whole, it fails to deliver a coherent or compelling
narrative.

Babygirl" - reality? Hypnose? A Story About Power, Desire, and Inner
Freedom

Babygirl is not a conventional love story. Desire is present in every
scene, but this is not a film about seduction for its own sake. It's
about the complex territory where power, vulnerability, and identity .
Babygirl is not, at its core, a film about sex - it's about trauma,
perception, and the fragile boundary between reality and what we
construct in our own minds. I watched it again and again... so many
symbols.

The surface version of the ending is simple: her boss tells her Samuel
is in Tokyo - the "official" truth, the version for everyone else. Yet
the very next shot shows Samuel in their hotel room, with the dog,
exactly as before. This contradiction is the film's most deliberate
ambiguity. Is it real? Or is it just in her head?

If you watch closely, the clues point to hypnosis. In the therapy
session, during trance, we see rapid, fragmented flashes: the hotel
room, Samuel, the dog climbing over her. These images reappear almost
identically in the final scene. That repetition isn't accidental - it's
a cinematic breadcrumb trail suggesting that the final moment might be a
mental reconstruction, not a physical meeting.

The dog is the perfect "red thread" through the story: 1. In the first
scene, it doesn't even seem to be Samuel's - he calms it with a tone of
control, not affection.

2. When she visits him in the hospital, the dog becomes emotionally
linked to him - a symbol of comfort.

3. In hypnosis, the dog is placed right in the fantasy of reconnection.

4. In the final scene, the dog is there exactly as it was in the trance,
which could mean the entire ending is a replay of that mental image.

The lighting, the framing, and the dreamlike quality of the final shot
match the "oniric" tone of the hypnosis sequence, not the grounded
realism of the rest of the film. And the boss's "He's in Tokyo" line
works like an anchor to reality - everything after it may be her mind's
rebuttal: "No. I can still see him." Then there's the line when her
husband asks if Samuel is "relevant" to her as a director, and she
replies, "We're all irrelevant." On the surface, it's cold, dismissive.
Symbolically, it's a declaration that objective reality and social
labels no longer matter to her. What matters is her own experience - and
if she creates it in her mind, it's just as valid as if it happened in
the flesh.

This ties perfectly into her profession. She doesn't sell objects or
standard services - she sells stories. A beautifully packaged version of
reality where people are buying a feeling and an image, not something
tangible.

In her career, she masters the art of selling perceptions.

In her personal life, she uses the same skill to create in her mind a
closure reality never gave her.

That's why the Harvest scene is so layered. On one level, it's just a
product launch - an innovative robot tied to emotional intelligence,
making it a standout in the fictional market she describes. But for
those catching the subtext, there's irony: she publicly credits her
husband Jacob with the idea of merging cold technology with empathy,
while their own marriage lacks that same emotional connection. Is it a
sincere professional nod, or a quiet jab wrapped in a smile?

There's a pivotal psychological moment when her husband asks if Samuel
is "relevant" to her as a director, and she replies: "We are all
irrelevant." On the surface, it sounds cold and defensive - a quick way
to shut the topic down. But symbolically, it's a declaration that no
role, no social label, and no formal relationship truly matter to her
anymore. The only thing that counts is her personal experience and how
she chooses to live it.

In the context of the ending, this becomes crucial: if "everyone is
irrelevant," (as she says to Jacob) then objective reality itself is
secondary. What matters is the reality she creates for herself - even if
it exists only in hypnosis. That's why, for her, the final scene with
Samuel is equally valid whether it happened physically or only in her
mind.

The beauty of Babygirl is that it refuses to give you a universal key.
You can watch it as a romantic ambiguity - believing Samuel is truly
there. Or you can see it as a deeply psychological resolution - her
mind, in hypnosis, building the perfect final meeting so she can let go.
Both versions are valid, because the film's real question isn't "Is this
real?" but "Does it matter?" Sometimes, what happens in your mind can
change you as much as something that happens in real life. My question:

Bravo!

Intriguing but Ultimately Forgettable

Babygirl explores how people build their lives around control and
appearances, but end up starving their deeper needs. Romy's affair isn't
really about lust, it's her psyche forcing her to confront the part of
herself she's buried: the need to surrender, to feel without performing.
The film suggests that intimacy and self-acceptance only come when we
risk exposing the hidden, "unacceptable" sides of ourselves instead of
hiding behind perfection. In the end, it lands somewhere between
intriguing and underwhelming, watchable in the moment but forgettable
the second it's done.

A confusing take on Power, Desire, and Unspoken Boundaries

The film was a bit of a mixed bag for me. The film follows Romy, a
powerful older woman played by Nicole Kidman, who gets involved with her
much younger intern. The idea of power and vulnerability in
relationships is definitely interesting, and Kidman gives a strong
performance. However, the story sometimes felt a bit slow, and some of
the scenes were pretty intense. I couldn't always connect with the
characters, but the way the film explores complex emotions and
boundaries in life did make me think. It's not a bad watch, but it
didn't totally hit the mark for me.

However the end didn't make any sense to me. It eventually felt like old
people learning to communicate about sexual compatibility and
preferences.

All for money, not to sell an idea

I recently watched *Babygirl* starring Nicole Kidman, and I have to say,
I'm giving it a rating of 5. While Nicole Kidman attempts to deliver a
strong and committed performance-she makes you wonder she has accepted
this role for money

From the start, I felt like the story leaned too heavily on familiar and
overused themes of power, desire, and complicated relationships. Instead
of offering new insights or emotional depth, it seemed to recycle old
tropes without much payoff. The characters, including Kidman's, lacked
real chemistry and depth, which made it hard for me to connect with or
care about what was happening on screen.

The pacing was slow in parts, and the film's ambiguous take on sensitive
topics like consent and manipulation left me more frustrated than
thoughtful. Honestly, I don't think movies like this are in the best
interest of the audience. They risk alienating viewers by focusing on
shock value and unresolved themes rather than genuine storytelling.

In the end, while I can appreciate Kidman's effort and the film's
stylish look, *Babygirl* just didn't resonate with me. I wouldn't
recommend it to others looking for a meaningful or entertaining movie
experience.

Positive review

This is the best movie i have watched. Its characters are perfect.
Babygirl is a cinematic masterpiece that will leave audiences spellbound
and eager for more. The 2024 film is a tour-de-force that explores
themes of identity, family, and the complexities of human relationships.

The movie tells the story of Babygirl, a young woman who finds herself
at a crossroads in her life. As she navigates the challenges of
adulthood, Babygirl must confront her own demons and learn to let go of
the past.

The film features stunning performances from the entire cast, with
delivering a standout performance as the titular character. The
chemistry between the actors is palpable, and the dialogue is witty and
engaging.

One of the standout elements of "Babygirl" is its cinematography. The
film features breathtaking visuals, with a keen attention to detail that
immerses the viewer in the world of the story. The score is equally
impressive, perfectly capturing the mood and tone of each scene.

Where "Babygirl" truly shines, however, is in its thoughtful and nuanced
exploration of its themes. The film raises important questions about
identity, family, and the complexities of human relationships, and it
does so with a sensitivity and empathy that is all too rare in modern
cinema.

Overall, "Babygirl" is a must-see film that will resonate with audiences
long after the credits roll. With its stunning performances,
breathtaking cinematography, and thoughtful exploration of its themes,
this movie is a true masterpiece that will leave you spellbound and
eager for more.
